div.head: The adventures of a gentleman in search of Miss Smith
THE ADVENTURES OF A GENTLEMAN IN SEARCH OF MISS SMITH.
CHAPTER I.
div.p: A fine steamer was dashing gallantly down the Hudson, toward the commercial metropolis of our country. The sun was setting gorgeously, behind the Highlands and the summer wind just rippled the sparkling waters. It was a brilliant evening, and the deck was crowded with groups of passengers, who appeared to enjoy the hour and the scene exceedingly.

Among the promenaders was a young man of refined and prepossessing appearance, dressed with extreme care; and his glittering watch-guard, seal-ring, and diamond pin, be trayed a fondness for ornament which might have become one of the opposite sex. He was a slender youth, of dark complex on and black eyes, and there was an expression about the mouth which indicated firmness of purpose, whole the remainder of the features expressed excitability of temperament, and impulsive feeling.

At each turn in his walk, the eyes of this young gentleman were irresistably attracted toward a group of three persons who occupied seats near the bow of the boat, or rather toward one member of the party. This was a young lady of slight and girl sh figure, brilliantly fair complexion, and blonde hair. She was not beautiful, but her face was eminently pleasing and attractive, and the bright good-humor, sparkling over it, was more to the taste of her young admirer than perfect beauty of feature would have been.

The quiet, elderly people, whom she enlivened by her sprightly sallies, were evidently her parents; and, from the appearance of the three, a stranger would have judged them to be respectable people in comfortable circumstances, who enjoyed the good things of this life, without making a display themselves or caring for that made by others.

Young as he evidently was, our hero was an observer, and he accurately divined the position occupied by these persons, who interested him so deeply; for he was already fathoms in love with the young girl, and was endeavoring to find some excuse for approaching the trio, sufficiently near to hazard an address to one of them.

Mr. Mortimer Grandval was as romantic a young gentleman as his name could appropriately have been bestowed upon. He was a southerner by birth, and in possession of a handsome, unencumbered property. He had graduated, very recently, at a northern university, and was now making a summer tour, preparatory to his return home in the fall to assume the management of his own affairs. He had strong faith in love at first sight, and he now firmly believed that some intuitive feeling of fitness attracted him so powerfully
toward her of the blonde hair and brilliant smile. The Fates destined her to become his, and doubtless they had been providentially thrown together, that the destiny decreed them should be fulfilled.

Thus reasoned Mr. Mortimer Grandval, and it seemed as if chance were determined to favor the hypothesis by allowing him an opportunity to gain the desired privilege of addressing her. The young lady arose from her seat to gain a better view of some point in the scenery, and her veil becoming detached from her bonnet, was wafted back among the crowd of passengers. There was a slight scramble between several gentlemen for the possession of it, for Grandval was not the only one attracted by this fresh and artless-looking girl; but our hero proved the fortunate one. With a deferential bow, he approached and presented it to her, at the same time uttering a few words which formed an opening for a conversation.

His manner was so respectful, and his appearance so evidently that of a gentleman that, after a slight scrutiny on the part of the parents, they joined in the conversation; thus giving their sanction to the new acquaintance formed by their daughter. Grandval was familiar with the scenery on the river, and he possessed fine natural tact, and agreeable descriptive powers. He could quote poetry, too, with the enthusiasm of a Sophomore, and the brightening eyes and kindling cheeks of his fair listeners betrayed the deepening interest with which they hearkened to his words.

When the supper-bell rang, he ventured to offer himself as her escort to the table; and after swallowing a cup of tea at nearly scalding temperature—of which fact, however, he was happily unconscious—he returned with her to the deck, and to the charms of moonlight, sentiment, and music—for there was a fine band on board, which played until a late hour.

It was a glorious summer night, and, oh! bliss ineffable! his new acquaintance leaned upon his arm, and promenaded with him, unaccompanied by papa and mamma. Gaining confidence as she became better acquainted, she quoted poetry in her turn, and Grandval discovered that a remarkable sympathy existed in their tastes and feelings. Like most of her young countrywomen, the fair stranger was an enthusiastic admirer of the productions of Willis, and she quoted some of his exquisite fancies in a voice of such clear music as enchanted the listener.

"I graduated at the same institution," said Grandval, "and I have often visited spots which were said to be favorite haunts of the poet, and wished that I, too, could gain inspiration from their loveliness. It is the glorious privilege of those who can touch the finer chords of our hearts, by the inspirations of their genius, to be enshrined therein with a species of reverential worship, which is not bestowed upon the author, but on the ideality which clothes in language the silent aspirations of the human soul."

"True; and, as I gaze on the scene which lies around us, his words involuntarily occur to me as applicable to this night. In a prose story, which no one else could have written, he describes a scene at Trenton Falls: 'a more omnipresent and radiant atmosphere of moonlight never sprinkled the wilderness with silver.'"
"I am sure I can go on and say, with perfect truth, 'it was a night in which to wish it might never be day again.'"
"Mary, my love," said the voice of mamma, "I think it is time for us to retire. The air is sensibly cooler, and it grows late."
Mary joined her for a moment, and petitioned for only another half hour. "It was a shame to retire to the cabin, and endeavor to sleep, when such a moon was shining over them."
The petition was granted, and the two resumed their promenade.

When she finally retired, Grandval felt as if the light of even that brilliant night bad departed with her, and he leaned over the balustrade and watched the rippling waters, as the boat cut her swift way through them, and recalled the winning manner and arch smile of his new acquaintance, with the conviction that they must become the charm of his home, or he was a desolate and undone man.

The thought suddenly occurred to him that he would find out the name of the parents by applying to the register. She, herself, bore the charmed one of Mary, and all the poetry linked with that sweet appellation came to his mind, and he instantly applied it to his late companion—believing her, in his heart, the brightest and loveliest of all the Marys that have ever lived.

He wended his way to the clerk's office, and, after some difficulty, found the name he sought; but never did man gain less information therefrom. He looked at it several moments in blank amazement, for it was so common a designation that it conveyed to him no idea of individuality. John Smith, wife and daughter, stared him in the face. A crowd of John Smiths arose before his mental vision; he had known at least a dozen himself, and as he now endeavored to recall them, he felt assured that he could not recognize one of them if they should suddenly appear before him.

John Smith! Absurd, for a man with such a patronymic to inflict upon his son the irreparable injury of bestowing upon him an equally common baptismal appellation! It is a wrong that can not be atoned for; that time will only deepen; for, save the John Smith of Pocahontas celebrity, what trump of Fame has ever bequeathed one of the numerous bearers of that name to the admiration or reverence of posterity? A man with such a cognomen should seek the most extraordinary appellation for his son. For instance, Melchesideck Smith, or Nebuchadnezzar Smith, or Aldibarontapho cophornio Smith, might stand some chance to be remembered, but simple John Smith at once takes his place amid the busy crowd as a nonentity—as one of a numerous legion of brothers bearing the same nondistinctive appellation.

Grandval had been so occupied with the daughter that he had neglected to remark the outer man of Mr. Smith with any degree of particularity, but he mentally resolved to do so on the morrow before they parted; for, in a city like New York, where the Smiths are numbered in legions, he might experience some difficulty in finding the real Simon Pure, and on the prosecution of this chance-acquaintance, he fully persuaded himself, depended his future happiness.

He retired to his berth after midnight, and tossed on his uneasy pillow until nearly dawn. He then fell into a deep sleep, which lasted several hours. When he awoke, the boat was in port, and, from the sounds which reached his ears, he knew that the passengers were rapidly departing. Should his new acquaintance leave before he again saw them! before he ascertained their place of residence! There was horror in the thought! He did not even know if they lived in New York; they might reside in Louisiana, or at the opposite extremity of the Union, for aught he knew; and the idea of being compelled to search over this wide-spread country for John Smith, with a daughter bearing the equally common name of Mary, was terrible! His pilgrimage might rival that of Evangeline, and end in as unsatisfactory a manner.

With trembling haste he performed his toilet, and, without being very precise as to the tie of his cravat, or the curl of his hair, he rushed forth amid the crowd of porters, hackney-coachmen, and others that usually encumber the way. A glance within the open doors of the ladies' cabin assured him that it was quire empty, and he hurried, in great perturbation, toward the clerk's office.
"Have all the lady passengers left?" he asked, in quite an excited manner.
"Every one, I believe, except a sick lady, who is under the care of the captain. Overslept yourself, eh? Any lady to complain of your neglect?"
"No; but I made an acquaintance I am sorry to lose sight of so soon. I wished to ascertain her residence—that is, the residence of her father."
"Eh? I know many of the people who were on board; they often travel by this line. Maybe I can help you," said the good natured clerk. "What was the name of the gentleman?"
"Smith—John Smith," replied our hero, with a crest-fallen expression.
The clerk uttered an expressive whistle.

"Sorry I can do nothing for you; but the Smiths are such a numerous family, there is no telling one from the other, 'specially the John Smiths. But there seems to be a party
on the wharf yet; perhaps they may prove to be your friends"

Grandval rushed out, in a state of great excitement. A girlish figure was springing into a carriage; he thought it must be Mary; another glance at the person of the gentleman who followed her convinced him that his conjecture was correct; he leaped on shore, ran as rapidly as he could for the various impediments which obstructed his way, and came near enough to the vehicle to see that it was occupied by the party he sough—to receive a smile of recognition from the fair Mary—when she was whirled rapidly away, and his cries to the driver to stop were unheard amid the Babel of surrounding sounds.

div.head: CHAPTER II.
div.p: IN a state of complete bewilderment, Grandval made his way on the boat again, and after giving his baggage in charge of a porter, he hurried toward the hallowed spot upon the deck on which he had first beheld his adorable Mary; but he was quite disgusted, and his sentimentality terribly outraged, at finding the place occupied by two stupid-looking children, belonging to the sick lady, who were quarreling over the division of bread and cheese, which one of them held in her soiled apron.

Almost execrating these infant innocents, he turned away, and hurried toward a cab in which he was taken, in a most wretched state of mind, to his boarding house, on —— street. It was kept by a widow of highly respectable connections, and with Mrs. Wilson, the quiet manners and gentlemanly appearance of young Grandval had rendered him quite a favorite. She happened to be at the parlor-window when the cab drove to the door, and she noticed his unusual paleness, and the air of wildness which the unsettled state of his feelings unconsciously imparted to him; she therefore came out and received him herself, with almost maternal solicitude.
"Glad to see you back again, Mr. Grandval; but, dear me, I hope you have not been ill. You look quite—quite done up, as one may say."

"Do I, indeed!" asked Grandval. "No, Mrs. Wilson, I have not been ill, but I have met with a sad disappointment—an adventure which may stamp my life for good or evil—a loss which, if not remedied, may produce fatal consequences."
"Dear me, I am sorry to hear that. Pray walk into my own sitting-room, and tell me all about it."

The young man felt the necessity of a confidant; his heart was overflowing with disappointment, and he must bestow is fullness on some one; moreover, it occurred to him that Mrs. Wilson's long residence in New York had probably made her well acquainted with many of the tribe of Smiths, more numerous in our day than the children of Israel in their palmiest hour; and she might be able to furnish him a clue to the residence of the veritable John. He therefore followed the good lady into her sanctum, and there related to her the history of the meeting on the steamer, and its consequences, frankly admitting that he had fallen irrevocably in love with the fair Mary at first sight.
Mrs. Wilson listened with an air of deep interest, and when he closed his narrative with a sigh, she said,

"You need not fall into a state of despondency about this affair, Mr. Grandval, for you may depend upon it Miss Smith will be easily found. I know many Smiths myself, and among them may be the family you seek. Describe this young lady to me; was she beautiful?"

"No—O—perhaps not beautiful, but exceedingly attractive; she is sprightly, animated, and evidently good-tempered. He who wishes a "bright spirit for his minister," would prefer her to a more regular beauty."
"A charming girl, no doubt; but what is her peculiar style? for I know a Mary Smith, and now I remember about it, her father's name is John. Perhaps she may be your lady-love"
Grandval caught at the suggestion eagerly,
"If she should prove so, Mrs. Wilson, I shall bless you, indeed. This young lady is very fair, with blue eyes and golden hair."
'A tall, delicate figure?" suggested Mrs. Wilson.
"Yes—that is, not very tall, but slender and sylph-like."

"Hem; the description tallies very well, allowing for the exaggeration of the lover Mary Smith is a nice girl, and a very good housewife, but I never found her quite so charming as you consider her. However, as I am not in love with her, that could not be expected. I can tell you, Mr. Grandval, you have made a more sensible choice than young men usually do; for Miss Smith makes the very best pickles and preserves of any young lady of my acquaintance."

"Pickles and preserves," repeated Grandval, with a tragi-comic air. "O, Mrs. Wilson, do not drive me quite beyond the limits of reason, by talking of such every-day affairs, when I feel as if I shall never again be able to eat any thing more than will barely sustain life until I discover the abode of my life's angel."

"Pickles will give an appetite sometimes," said the old lady, sententiously, "and preserves are also useful to wrap up pills for those diseased with fevers of any kind, so Mary's skill in that line may prove of some consequence yet, contemptuously as your speak of it. A talent for housekeeping is by no means to be despised, when a man is looking out for a partner for life."
The lover groaned in spirit. This was taking a utilitarian view of things which had never occurred to his young romance.

"Young men don't often think of these affairs before they rush into matrimony," continued sensible Mrs. Wilson, "but they very soon find out afterward, if the house is not in order, and the meals not well cooked. Then what a shaking and cuffing poor little Cupid gets! ten chances to one he is so unmercifully berated that he shakes his wings in scorn, and files away forever from those who were so unreasonable as to bring him no assistance in the shape of common sense, to aid him in his efforts to smooth for them the rugged path of life, by shedding the light of his presence over their household."
The latter portion of this speech showed that the good lady had something poetic mixed up with her every-day views of life and its duties, and Grandval listened with more respect.

"I am glad that I have been so fortunate as blindly to make a choice which so sensible a person as you are can approve," said the young man. "But, dear Mrs. Wilson, if, after all, your Mary Smith and mine should prove not to be the same person—ah, the thought distracts me!"
"But I am certain she must be the right one, Mr. Grandval, so you need not take on so. It is scarcely possible that two John Smiths can have a daughter Mary so perfectly alike."
"When shall I see her, madam? I am all impatience to ascertain if your conjecture be correct. I would set out this moment if it were possible. Can we not call this morning?"
Mrs. Wilson meditated a brief space, and then replied,

"I think we had better not be in so great a hurry; because, to tell you the truth, Mrs. Smith is one of the most particular women In the world, and if she is just off a journey, she will be very busy overlooking the house, and finding out how things have gone on in her absence. I can tell you she is'nt one of those mothers who allow their daughters to sit in the parlor entertaining company while they are busy about household matters; no, Mary goes heart and hand with her mother in everything she undertakes. Ah, Mr. Grandval, you will obtain a jewel of a wife."
"I am glad to hear it, Mrs. Wilson; but pray, when will it be proper to call? I shall not sleep until I ascertain the identity of your young friend with my new acquaintance."

"Well, as I've known these Smiths a long time, though I can't say I'm very intimate with them, I think I may venture to take you there this evening; 'specially as you are not an entire stranger, and a young man like yourself, who comes as a lover, is always graciously received."

Thus it was arranged, and Grandval retired to his room with a mind a little more at ease. He passed the day in looking over poetic extracts from which to call the most beautiful quotations for the evening's conversation, varying his employment by occasiona
visits to the mirrror, to ascertain if he was in a good looks as usual.

He had little appetite for his dinner, which Mrs. Wilson observed, and recommended to him some very fine pickles as a provocative, remarking, at the same time, that they were nearly as good as those manufactured by a certain fair friend of theirs, who should be nameless. Grandval blushed, and the other boarders looked at him as if he were some newly imported phenomenon of the animal species, in place of that very common specimen of the genus homo, a young gentleman very decidedly and verdantly in love.

Evening at last came, and after a most elaborate toilet, our lover joined Mrs. Wilson in such perturbation of spirits as was quite pitiable. He was evidently in such a tremulous state that she deeply sympathised with him, and made many efforts to direct his thoughts by conversing on such themes as she fancied would possess an interest for him; but she might as well have addressed her remarks to the man in the moon as to the earthly mortal who walked by her side in a state of nervous abstraction which rendered him oblivious of every thing that was passing around him.

After walking about eight squares, Mrs. Wilson announced that the end of their pilgrimage had arrived. Grandval looked up; they were in front of a red brick house which made one of a long row, all of which were exactly alike, and looked as if they were built for people who were all formed on the same pattern. It is difficult to fancy any individuality character among persons content to live in a brick row, and yet, if we could indeed play the part of the Diable Boiteux, we should find tragedy and comedy, happiness and misery, crime and integrity, dwelling side by side in those dull uniform looking walls.

To Grandval's eyes, the re brick was a temple which enshrined his divinity, and he felt almost vexed with his good friend when she called his attention to the glitter of the gaslights on the brass knobs upon the door.
"It is easy to see that this is the neatest, house in the row, Mr. Grandval. See, there is not another door handle half so brilliant all the way down."

The ring at the bell was promptly answered by a half grown girl, who looked as if shining from the recent application of soap and water; and her hair was smoothed on her round head as flatly as if it had been glued down. Her dress was very short, and rather narrow, but spotlessly clean.

A gas-light burned in the hall, and a lamp with a summer-shade stood in the front parlor. Grandval knew not why, but the aspect of this room struck a chill through him, even on this summer night. It was so formal—so precisely neat in every respect, that it seemed impossible for any genial flow of soul ever to take place within its walls. The chairs were all covered with brown linen, and stood marshalled in stiff array around the room; this-sombre drapery invested every thing, and seemed to cast a "brown horror" over the apartment.

It is true that vases of flowers stood on the marble mantle, but they were made of shells, and the wiry stems stood out in regular order around the parent stalk as stiff as the quills on a porcupine. No artificial imitation of nature which has yet been attempted is so uninteresting to the imagination as shell flowers. Hard, stiff, scentless things, they excite surprise by their ingenuity, but no sentiment can possibly be attached to them; and Grandval, who thought the treasures of Flora the only fitting offering for one so young and fair as his Mary, turned with disgust from the glittering counterfeits of nature's fairest daughters.

Several handsomely bound volumes were placed in orderly array upon a table, and while awaiting Miss Smith's appearance, Grandval ventured to take one up. It opened of itself to a receipt for making preserved ginger, and to his surprise he found that a copy of Miss Leslie's cookery book had found its way into the parlor. Curiosity now induced him to look over the other volumes, and to his increased astonishment he found them of the same character; they were all works on gastronomy and the art of living well.
Mrs. Wilson remarked his surprise, and glancing at them, she said,

"Ah, Mr. Smith is . He is a bon vivant of the highest type, and thinks that people only live to eat. He says that those who teach us something new in the art of cookery deserve the highest place of honor; so he has had his favorite authors in that line elegantly bound, and promoted them to a place in the parlor."

"A singular fancy, I must confess," commenced Grandval, but his words died on his lips, and he felt as if he would have been much obliged to the insensible floor if it would have taken pity on his confusion at that instant, opened wide its wooden jaws, and have allowed him to pass into the depths of darkness below. In the open doorway just in front of him appeared a young lady, toward whom Mrs. Wilson advanced with alacrity, at the same time addressing her as her dear Mary thus leaving no gleam of hope in the stunned soul of Mr. Mortimer Grandval—for, O, terrible to relate! the person who thus appeared was not the Miss Smith. The resemblance which had deluded him into the belief that it might be his Mary, was just enough to warrant the supposition, while at the same time it was an insult to the fresh and blooming image enshrined in his heart, to compare it with the hard-looking, light-haired girl who was now introduced to him as Miss Mary Smith.

The young lady bowed stiffly and coldly, and seemed evidently surprised at his perturbation. Mrs. Wilson regarded it as only the bashfulness of a young lover, and while the cold perspiration was bursting from his brow, she went on with great volubility to say that at the request of her late traveling companion, she had brought him to pay his respects; as he hoped to be permitted to cultivate an acquaintance so auspiciously begun.

The lady turned her light blue eyes on the shivering form of the abashed young man, and he felt as if they might have been little pellets of ice with a small spot of paly blue in the center of each, so chilling was the expression they wore, "Excuse me, Mrs. Wilson, but I am entirely at a loss to understand you," she said in a voice as dry and harsh as her form was bony. "I have not been on a journey this summer, though we contemplate making one. In fact, we should have gone before this time, but just as we were ready to leave, the discovery was made, that the household stores prepared by ourselves, had suffered from the great heat of the weather, and many of them were in a state of fermentation. Under these circumstances, it was impossible to leave before the mischief was remedied."
Grandval could have groaned audibly, but he courageously pent up his feelings within his own breast, and forced himself to say,

"I beg your pardon, Miss Smith, but the similarity in your name, has led me into a strange mistake. I made the acquaintance of Miss Mary Smith on the North River yesterday, and as I neglected to ascertain her place of residence, I ventured to call with my good friend, Mrs. Wilson, hoping you would prove to be the lady."

Miss Smith grew more stately every moment as this explanation proceeded, and her eyes appeared to become colder and colder, until little points of ice seemed actually to radiate from them. With great stateliness she said,

"My name, sir, is not Smith, but Smythe, as you might easily have ascertained, if you had consulted the directory. I should be extremely sorry to be confounded with the vulgar tribe of Smiths, whose ancestors must have been either gun makers, or horse shoe manufactures; as in ancient times people are said to have derived their names from the handicraft they followed, or from some estate,"

Grandval had a great inclination to inquire of her how her ancestors obtained theirs, but he prudently refrained, and relapsed into a state of wretched recklessness, while the two ladies kept up a constrained conversation, in which he made not the slightest effort to join. Miss Smythe had frozen him up completely, and as he looked at her he wondered that Mrs. Wilson had not vaunted her powers of making ice-cream, as well as pickles; though he mentally acknowledged that she need only look into a jar of the latter, and the highest point of acidity would be attained.

In a state of completed obliviousness as to what was passing around him, Grandval sat a wretched half hour with the murmur of conversation ringing in his ears, and then mechanically obeyed the motion of Mrs. Wilso
to leave. With a profound bow, and a few muttered words, he bade adieu to Miss Smythe with the devout hope that he should never behold her fair face again.

"Dear me, who would have believed that such a blunder could be made!" ejaculated Mrs. Wilson when they were fairly outside of the house. "And the description you gave applied so well to this young lady too!"

"Don't say that Mrs. Wilson if you please," said our hero in a state of exasperation. "I never could have said any thing that could lead you to suppose me quite dull enough to fall in love with such a mummy as that girl Why she is an absolute fright! I told you my Mary is a sylph, and you seem to think she is as bony as Miss Fox."

"I'm not acquainted with that lady," said Mrs. Wilson who was guiltless of literary airs, "but I am sure you said she is fair and golden-haired, and so is this young lady. Besides, you said she is not beautiful, and I am sure neither is Miss Smythe."

"No, by the Mass! a more lack-lustre imitation of humanity I hope never to see. She surely does not inherit the paternal fondness for the good things of this life, or she would, scarcely be as attenuated as she is."
"I can not say as to that, but he certainly excels in preparing them, and I am sorry you missed the chance of such a pattern-wife as she will make."

"My dear Mrs. Wilson, such a regret would almost prove you to be no friend to my happiness. If such a woman could win me, I would give her leave to bestow her choicest acid upon me, as she does on her boasted pickles."

We leave the reader to imagine the state of mind in which the disappointed Grandval spent the night. We can not assert that the did not even tear his hair, as he perambulated his floor through its long hours, and thought of his terrible disappointment. The image of the true Mary Smith arose before him more charming than ever, when he contrasted her with the counterfeit he had been deceived into seeking.

div.head: CHAPTER III.
div.p: THE apartment occupied by our hero joined that of another single gentleman, on whom Mrs. Wilson's allusion at dinner that day had not been lost, as, in fact few things were, for Mr. Medler possessed the most insatiable curiosity, and an extreme fondness for assisting his friends out of difficulties; which assistance frequently tended only to plunge them deeper into what they were seeking to extricate themselves from.

Mr. Medler was by several years the senior of Grandval, and possessed the further advantage of being city bred, so that he considered himself up to any thing. The distracted perambulations of his neighbor were distinctly audible to him through the thin partition which divided their room, and he mentally decided to find out what it was all about before the following day was over.
In pursuance of his plan, he knocked at Grandval's door as soon as he was dressed, there by arousing that unhappy wight from a light slumber into which he had fallen about daylight.
"Who is there?" he peevishly demanded.
"O, you're alive are you?" replied the voice of his fellow-boarder, "May I Come in?"
"Yes, if you wish it; the door is not locked."

Medler entered and found Grandval lying on the outside of the bed in the same clothes he had worn on the preceding evening, with the exception of his coat, which his excited promenade had rendered inconveniently warm, and it had therefore been laid aside. He looked pale, and the livid circles beneath his eyes showed that he really suffered.

"My dear fellow," said Medler. 'I heard you moving about all night, and feared you were ill, but I would'nt intrude then, because I thought you would call our if you needed assistance. What's in the wind, my boy? Been losing more money than you can conveniently pay?"
"I never gamble; it is a worse loss than money," he feebly said.
"Ha, well, that is according to one's own estimate of things Now to me money is the representative of every thing in the shape of human felicity; therefore I estimate its loss above every other."
"There are many things it can not buy nevertheless."
"As a lost heart for instance," suggested Medler determined to hazard a bold stroke. "Any body can see with half an eye, that you have fallen over head in love; come isn't it so now?"
Grandval sighed heavily.
"If I could only find the girl I am in love with, I shouldn't care," he said.
"What, parents opposed? sent her out of the way? The deuce! More romantic than agreeable that!"
"No, that is not it. I have lost all clue to her, through my own want of forethought."
"Pooh! that is easily remedied. Apply to the director—find out her father's residence—I will scrape up an acquaintance, and introduce you all regular."
"But, but, the name is the difficulty.
"You don't mean to say that you fell in love with the girl to the point you've reached, and did not find out her name?"
"No, I know her name, certainly, but that does not help me much."
"What is it then, in Heaven's name?"
"Mary Smith."
Mr. Medler looked nonplussed a moment but he brightened up and briskly said.
"Well, it her father's name isn't John, we can manage matters yet?"
"But unfortunately her father's name is John," said the lover despairingly, and the friend sat still, and hummed a tune, in a state of despondency. Presently he slowly said,
"It never was asserted that Jack Medler was not ready with an expedient for any mischance. My advice is, to call a convention of all the John Smiths in the city, and then pick out your man."

"But I only met them on a steamboat. I do not remember the old gentleman; it was the daughter I fell in love with, and as I had no intention of so soon losing sight of them, I scarcely noticed the appearance of the parents."
The adviser again seemed puzzled.
"Ah, but that is bad; but couldn't you ask each one in the assembly, if he has a daughter Mary, who is the most charming girl in the city?"

"And perhaps half the men present, would reply in the affirmative; for Mary is unfortunately as common a designation as Smith, and fathers often think their daughters mere charming than any one else considers them; no that will never do."

"Ah, well, perhaps not. Tell me the whole story, and it maybe I can help you. I have been in the city all my life, and know a pretty considerable number of the Smith family myself. At all events, I will do my best to assist you in your search."
"Thank you, Medler, I feel the need of some one to advise with, and I know you are sincere in your offer."
"You may say that my good fellow. I have a zeal in my friend's service, if I sometimes lack discretion. But let me hear this heart history, if you please."

Glad to find a sympathizing listener, Grandval related the story of his unfortunate case up to the close of the last evening, and Medler chuckled over the description of Miss Smythe, and the chilling process he had undergone.

"Know those persons myself, dined there once on turtle and venison; fine dinner, very, but a tun a wine wouldn't warm the mother and daughter, while the father is jolly as Bacchus. They are aristocratic, and only tolerate our good landlady because she happens to be connected with some of the upper ten; though what advantage the relationship is, no body can see, for her rich cousins do nothing for her in her reverses, poor soul. If Miss Smythe had known you were from the south, of good family, and owner of a fair share of cotton bales, she might have thawed a little."
"Do not talk of her; the recollection of her is odious to me. Rather let us decide on the best course for discovering my own Mary."

"Ah, true, Mary is a sweet name, but I could wish that in the present instance the lady bore one a little less common. Now it is by no means usual for ladies to bear the names of our sex, but it is sometimes done, and if this young girl were only Miss Jemmy
Smith, we might soon overcome the difficulty. However, we can but set our wits to work, and it shall never be said that Jack Medler was baffled in what he undertook to perform."

We have said that Mr. Medler was fond of assisting his friends; in fact, he was quite a philanthropist in his way, the only misfortune being that the aid he rendered was often of exceedingly doubtful advantage to the recipient. While Grandval confided his case to him, a scheme floated through his brain by which he thought two friends might be benefitted at one stroke, if he could only bring the plan to bear.

"This young fellow is green," thought the city man, "and easily caught by a pretty face He has never seen this girl but once, and why shall not any other Miss Smith answer as well, even if her name is not Mary? My pretty cousin Kitty Smith, is as charming as this young lady, no doubt, and I know she will be glad to make a good match. If I can bring it to pass, old Jeremiah would accommodate me with that other five hundred as a reward for ridding him of the eldest of six girls. Kate is a dashing girl, and a few smiles and sentimental speeches will soon win this youngster's heart from the other one; then hey presto for a merry weddin."

The last thought inspired him with such gleeful anticipations, that he snapped his fingers, and commenced a species of tattoo with his feet which caused his young friend to stare at him with astonishment.
"What is the matter?" he asked.

"Matter? O, nothing," replied Mr. Medler, in some confusion, "only you see I was thinking that we will soon be on the right track. I just happen to remember a Miss Smith who must be the one you are in pursuit of, and I'll tell you the reason why I think it must be the same. This young lady is a distant relative of my own, and I know certainly that she visited Albany last week in company with her parents, and returned yesterday morning."
This was a pure invention on the part of Mr. Medler, but it answered the purpose he wished, for Grandval was eager to believe him and readily permitted himself to be duped. He started up, exclaimin.
"My dear friend, you give me new life! Why did I not apply to you at once? Shall we seek her to-day? I am all impatience to behold her again."

"Softly, softly, my dear boy, I understand all that, and will set about obtaining an introduction for you as speedily as possible, but these things must be managed with care sometimes. The fact is, old Je—that is my respectable cousin John Smith—belongs to the class of particulars, and he does not permit every one to visit his daughter in the character of a suitor, who may happen to take a fancy to her on a steamboat. I must see him, tell him who you are, and request permission to introduce you into his family circle."

As this sounded very plausible and highly respectable, too, Grandval acquiesced in the necessity, and after a few more questions which were satisfactorily answered by Medler, Grandval arose in better spirits, and proceeded to make himself look less like a wanderer from the world of unrest, and more like a young gentleman of the nineteenth century, who was fully conscious of a fair portion of good looks.

Mrs Wilson was happy to see Mr. Grandval better than she had expected, after the adventure of the preceding evening, and she was quite electrified in the course of the morning, when he entered her room, and jested quite merrily on the mistake they had made.
"I am glad to see you are getting over it, Mr. Grandval You don't seem half so heart struck as you were yesterday."

"Perhaps Miss Smythe froze me so effectually last night that I have no warmth left in me. Oh, no, Mrs. Wilson, I have not forgotten my lady-love, nor proved false to her so soon, I assure you; but I have a strong hope—almost a certainty—of seeing her before twenty-four hours roll by."
Ah! Well I congratulate you; but how was the discovery of her residence brought about?"
"By the simplest means in the world. I have taken, one of my follow-boarders into my confidence, and he happens to know the family."
"How does he know it is the same one He may only lead you into a worse scrape than I did."
"Oh, several circumstances convince me that there can be no mistake in the present instance. Medler is too keen to be deceived in a matter of the kind."

"I don't know; men are not often more sagacious than women, in such affairs, and I was mistaken. Besides, Mr. Medler is notorious for getting others into difficulties; he has the best intentions in the world, but always acts with the greatest want of judgment. I am sorry he happens to be your adviser."

"Set your fears at rest dear Madame; I am certain that we are on the right track this time. In fact, the young lady is a relation of his own. Singular that it should turn out so, but fact is sometimes stranger than fiction."

In the meantime, Mr. Medler proceeded toward one of the most genteel portions of the city, and rang at the door of a house, struccoed and painted in imitation of stone, with pilasters and columns in front, and a small green yard, in which vegetated a few stunted and miserable-looking evergreens. This was evidently the abode of pretension, and Mr. Medler smiled as he glanced into the half open hall-door, and saw a young lady dressed in a very loose and rather soiled morning-wrapper, with her hair still in curl-papers. She caught a glimpse of his figure, and was about to vanish, when he called to her—
"Never mind, Kit, it is only I, and I wish to see you particularly."
With a hop, skip, and jump, and young girl thus addressed approached him, and held our her hand.

"So it's only you, sure enough, Cousin Jack and pray what brings you here so early this morning? See, I have not even had time to dress my hair, you horrid Vandal. But you are always taking one by surprise."

"Something is sometimes gained in that way, Coz. For instance, if I had fallen in love with your hyacinthine locks, last evening, I should have been quite disenchanted this morning, at finding them converted into horned snakes that might rival those of Medusa."
The girl laughed, and put up her hands toward the long rolls of paper around which her curls were twisted, as if endeavoring to shelter them from observation.

"Never mind, Kate, I am not in love with you, nor likely to become so, as you know very well. Let us go into the boudoir, as I believe you call it, and have a sensible talk. I know you can be rational sometimes."
"Thank you; and I also know that you can be complimentary sometimes, cousin of mine. Come in, and let me hear what your wisdom has to say."

She led the way into a small apartment opening from the drawing-room, which was ornamented with pictures and statues in abundance; but amid the redundancy of ornament, the lack of good taste was at once apparent. Every thing was overdone.

The young lady threw herself into the cor- corner
vis a vis, luxuriously cushioned, and motioned to her visitor to take the opposite seat. Medler obeyed, and then inquired—
"Well, Kate, how do you and young Simons get along? Has he asked the momentous question yet?"
Miss Smith pouted, and, after a pause, said—
"What can one make of such a stupidly-bashful man as he is? I know he is in love with me, but I do not believe he will ever have sufficient self-possession to ask any woman to marry him."
"Ah, so much the better just now, for I was afraid you were entangled there, and my present views for you might be thwarted."
"What do you mean, Jack?"
"Simply that if young Simmons is a good match, I can almost insure you a much better one, by a little tact and management on your part."
The girl listened attentively, and, after a moment's reflection, replied—

"You know that my position at home is not happy, Cousin, for we are a house divided against itself, and one and all devoted to that most uncomfortable way of living—mere outside show. You also know that every day I am reminded that I am the eldest of six daughters, and nearly twenty, without having yet had a serious offer. Under the circumstances, no one can wonder that I wish to marry some good man with whom I can live respectably
Now who is this new lover, and what part am I to play to win him?"

"He is a handsome young man, about two years your senior; independent in fortune, and of good manners. All that is requisite is for you to put another Miss Smith out of his romantic head, and usurp her place yourself."
"If he is already in love, it seems to me an idle speculation on your part, and a waste of smiles and graces on mine."

"Not at all. He has never seen the girl but once, and that on a steamboat; they walked in the moonlight, and talked sentiment until he lost his wits completely. You can get up a very pretty flirtation when you have mind to, and I advise you to try your powers on him. As clever a girl as you are can surely manage this verdant young chap."
"But tell me who he is—every thing you know about him—that I may judge of the expediency of taking the trouble."

Mr. Medler forth with related the adventures of Grandval, at which Miss Kate laughed merrily, but she became a little serious when she ascertained that he was really well educated, independent, and free to act for himself. Their consultation ended by permission being accorded to introduce the young gentleman that evening.

Mr. Medler returned to his friend in high glee; but fearful of being questioned too closely, he took care to dine out, and only to arrive at Mrs. Wilson's late in the evening. Although he was not at all scrupulous on the score of truth, he thought it as well to avoid departing from it as far as possible in the present instance, as no one could foresee the denonément denouément of the plot he had undertaken to conduct. To Grandval's look of eager inquiry, he replied,

"All right, my good fellow. I have smoothed the way for your introduction, and the fair Smith will receive you this evening with the full consent of Pa and Ma, and even including that of brother Jonas."
"She has a brother, then?"
"Lots of 'em—two older than herself, and two younger, besides five junior sisters."
"Quite an extensive family," said Grandval; "but if they are all as charming as Mary, their home must be a heaven on earth."

"Then—O, yes—very blissful, indeed. Excellent people, the Smith's are; none better; but, my dear fellow, it is time to make your toilette," so saying, he passed hurriedly into his room, leaving his young dupe in high spirits to prepare for the intended visit.

Dressed to the highest point of the becoming, Grandval entered the cab of Medler, and with a quickly-beating heart, was driven toward the mansion of Mr. Jeremiah Smith. The hall and parlors were brilliantly lighted and excited as he was, Grandval remarked the showy appearance of every thing, and he was not as favorably impressed as he had expected to be by the home of the quiet looking people he had met on the steamer.

In the front parlor was a young gentleman of tall figure, sandy hair, and parchment complexion, who was introduced as Mr. Jonas Smith. An elderly lady, who strikingly resembled her son, sat on a sofa, and Grandval bowed to her in a species of be wilderment, for it seemed impossible that this bedizened figure could be the same matronly woman in black, whom he had lately traveled with.

Mrs. Smith wore her light hair or wig in short spiral curls that hung down in an even files to her eyebrows, and were not even divided in the center. Beneath these peered a pair of small, sharp looking eyes, whose expression was not softened by the remainder of the features. Above this array of curls, which looked more like little wisps of dried hay than any thing else, was placed an elaborate cap, composed of flowers and small bits of blonde. The artificial tinting of the cheeks and lips completed a toute ensemble any thing but pleasing to the visitor.
With a painful contraction of the heart, Grandval bowed before her, and received her affected salutation. He found means to whisper to Medler.
"Get me out of this, Jack, for we're in the wrong box again. I never saw this lady before."
"Too late now, old fellow, you must spend the evening, at all events," returned Medler in the same tone. "Wait till the daughter comes in—she is a regular smasher, and no mistake."

Grandval sank into a seat, feeling himself a victim to the most untoward of all circumstances, while Mrs. Smith arranged the lace around her hands, spread out her fan, and prepared herself for conversation.
"A delightful day we have enjoyed, Mr. Grandly, I am sure, as I said to my daughter this morning, It'ly could'nt produce finer sun-shine than we walked in to day."
Before Grandval could reply, her son gruffly said,

"What else would you expect but hot sunshine at this season, ma'am? I dare say Mr. Grandval has been sufficiently melted in it to appreciate all its heating qualities. Foreigners say that we always begin a conversation by speaking of the weather, which is very true. Since I saw the observation, I make it a point never to do it. One American, at least, will repudiate the custom. How is cotton, Mr. Grandval?"

If he had asked the price of the horned horse or any other physical phenomenon, he might just as soon have expected a satisfactory reply from our young gentleman, for he had not yet entered on the management of his own property, and only cared to know that he derived from it an income more than sufficient for his most extravagant wants. He simply replied,
"I do not know; I have never interested mysel in commercial affairs. I believe the poet's corner is more frequently consulted by me than the prices current."
"Ah-h-h—not a business man, I perceive. As a grower of the staple, I thought you would naturally take an interest in its value."

"In years to come, I may do so, but hitherto my property has been under the management of an uncle, who is an experienced planter. Since my majority, I have been absent from home, and have had no hing to do but receive the income and appropriate it as suits myself."
Mrs. Smith listened, and her small eyes sparkled.
"What a fortunate thing it will be for Kate if she can only win him," she thought; and Mr. Jonas mentally determined that his visit to their house should not be made without some result.

At that instant a slight rustling noise was heard near the door, and a young lady dressed in white appeared. Grandval, at the first glimpse was struck with her showy appearance. Her figure was tall and slightly inclined to embonpoint, and her complexion brilliantly fair, while her eyes were large, dark and languishing. Her black hair hung in long ringlets in front, and her rosy lips unclosed on a set of white and regular teeth.

Altogether, Miss Smith, if not the one sought, was a very pleasing looking girl, and by no means an objectionable acquaintance, thought Grandval. As she advanced into the room she made a little theatrical start as her eye fell on our hero, and uttered a slight exclamation. Medler hastened to introduce his friend, and then the young lady blushed with the most charming confusion, and said,
"I was under the impression that I was to meet an acquaintance in Mr. Grandval. My cousin led me to believe that I should see in him one I have already had the pleasure of meeting while traveling."
"Travelling! when and where, I wonder," muttered Jonas. "To my certain knowledge, your travels have not extended beyond the limits of the city for the last year."

Grandval arose, made his most polite bow, and expressed his regrets that Miss Smith should have been disappointed in not recognizing an acquaintance in himself; that, however, could soon be remedied; he hoped they would soon become friends.

He felt himself wounderfully at his ease, and was soon engaged in quite a flirtation with Miss Kate, who used her eyes and her tongue with equal effect. Our hero was not quite so inexperienced as Mr. Medler imagined. He had been accustomed to ladies society during his sojourn at the University, and was able to talk sentiment and gallantry with his new acquaintance in a manner that both astonished and charmed her. From her cousin's description, she had expected to see quite a raw youth, and she was agreeably disappointed to find her powers lavished on one so well worthy of their exercise.

Medler judiciously devoted himself to the
entertainment of the Mama, who, on being snubbed by her son at the commencement of the interview, had subsided into a state of silent indignation, from which Cousin Jack's efforts at last aroused her. Common-places were uttered, and the faded curls and brilliant artificials shaken in concert with them until Cousin Jack thought his five hundred hardly earned, even if he eventually succeeded in loosening the purse-strings of the father of the family.

Mr. Jonas amused himself with making calculations with a pencil in a small book with a yellow leather cover, which he drew from his pocket. If the guest had been privileged to peep into these memoranda, he would have found calculations of the commissions due for selling cottons at various prices, which, in the imagination of the writer, were already as good as in the possession of the firm of Jeremiah Smith & Son.

In the meantime, Miss Smith inveigled Grandval into the boudoir under the pretext of hearing music by moonlight. A French window opened from this room on a balcony surrounded by iron railings, and ornamented with a stand of dusty flowers. In this two chairs were placed, and Miss Kate tuned her guitar in a patch of moonlight that fell between two neighboring chimney-tops, and was sufficient to light up her instrument and her lilly hands, while the remainder of her person rested in the shadowy star-lit air.

She sang passably, and talked very well; Grandval was amused and interested, but Miss Smith was mistaken in fancying that she was making a lasting impression upon his heart. That was irrevocably the property of the fair snow drop, whose image he cherished only the more fondly from the disappointments he encountered in finding her. He had tact enough to understand Miss Smith at a glance, and was quite willing to indulge her fondness for flirtation; never dreaming that any thing serious could be expected to grow out of this chance visit to her family.
"This is indeed a lovely night!" exclaimed the young lady, casting up her eyes in affected ecstacy.

"Lovely is the true epithet, Miss Smith, for I think it was made to talk love in," replied Grandval, with theatrical emphasis, as he stood in a graceful attitude before her. "I could make the hackneyed quotation—
"On such a night as this young Jessica," etc. but I forbear, as it must be well known to you, and I would not repeat what has become common place in such a presence, or in so poetic a scene as the one before me. It might inspire even my dull wit with such thoughts as the world does not willingly lt die."

"I am sure you are a poet, Mr. Grandval. You talk like one, and then you are from the land of the orange and the vine. I really thing that the very sight of an orange grove would inspire me with the divine afflatus."

"Unluckily I am a little too far north for the cultivation of the orange, and the view that oftenest rises up before my mental vision, is a field of dead cotton stalks, raising their brown and shrivelled arms toward heaven in every degree of crookedness that can be imagined, as if imploring the removal of their unsightliness from the fair face of nature."

"O! you horror! you destroyer of one's ideal pictures!" exclaimed the young lady. "I have imagined a palace-like building raising its stately front amid the green foliage and snowy blossoms of a lovely orange grove, on which cluster the ripened fruit and the fragrant flowers at the same time A gleam of silvery waters through a wide park on which stand noble forest trees, the growth of centuries, completes the picture."

"The homes of many of the very wealthy a little nearer the tropics, may realize your fancy sketch; but, in my state, by far the larger portion of the planters belong to the juste milieu, and with them comfort outweighs ostentatious show. Imagine a cottage building surrounded by wide galleries, and shaded by trees sufficiently trimmed to allow a free circulation of air; a neat fence, or an ever-green hedge forming the boundary to a yard often large enough to be dignified with the name of lawn, if the owner is ambitious. About a quarter of a mile off, is seen a small village, consisting of two parallel rows of houses with small gardens attached to them and often a narrow enclosure in front, in which a fruit tree is permitted to grow, provided the owners will not devour the fruit before it ripens."
"It is a fair picture, but then the producers are——" she hesitated, as if unwilling to wound him by uttering the thought that was in her mind.

"Slaves, you would say," continued Grandval. "That is true, and to be lamented, but since we must have them in our midst, we must do the best we can with them; and those orderly, well-cared for blacks, are in a very superior condition, I assure you, not only to many of their own color but to hundreds of their white brethren to be found in this very city. Within an hour's walk from this pleasant home of yours, I can find scenes that humanity must weep and shudder over. Let the philanthropist enter those and purge them, and then let him say to his southern brother, 'thou committest a wrong against thy fellow man by holding him in bondage.' Armed with the evidence of his far-reaching benevolence, which had swept crime and suffering from his own door, the slave-holder would meet him in the spirit of kindliness, and the means of ridding our country of this curse be jointly discussed in the spirit of anmity which should exist between the sons of this vast heritage, and not, as now, be sounded as the tocsin of political warfare. But pardon me, Miss Smith, we have diverged widely from the orthodox topics usually discussed by young ladies and gentlemen, on occasions like the present. Will you sing for me again?"
The tinkle of the guitar arose, and Miss Smith caroled a gay air, after which the sound of a voice near to Grandval informed him that the party in the drawing-room was increased by another arrival.

"It is mon cher papa," said his fair companion, starting up with an affected vivacity. "He will never forgive me if I delay presenting so agreeable an acquaintance as yourself to him. Allons—let us abjure moonlight for lamplight and the pleasures of the social circle."

Grandval followed her through the boudoir, and was introduced to an elderly gentleman, who was very bald and very white; he looked as if he had spent all the days of his life in the shades of his counting house, with no gleam of physical or mental sunshine to play upon his outward or inner man. It was evident that Mr. Smith was a hard, dry man of ledgers, whose ideas seldom soared beyond cent per cent. and the thought suggested itself to Grandval, that the over-dressed woman in the hay-colored wig, must have been the representative of a certain portion of real estate, or her mercantile partner would never have selected her as his companion in the voyage of life. It solved a doubt in his mind as to Mr. Smith's entire sanity when he made the choice, as he had been mentally accusing that respectable individual of remarkable want of taste in his judgment of the fairer part of creation. As to himself, he regarded Mrs. Smith as a frightful specimen of the sex, whom it would be a penance to be even distantly connected with, and wondered how so passable a girl as Kate could be the daughter of such a mother.
Miss Smith skipped toward her impassive papa, and seizing his chilly hand, made a point, of carrying it to her lips, and said—

"Permit me, dearest father, to have the pleasure of presenting you to a delightful new friend, for whose acquaintance we are indebted to cousin Jack. Mr. Grandval, my father will appreciate you, I assure you."

With great show of courtesy for him, Mr. Smith put forth his hand, and took that of our hero in its clammy clasp, while he scanned him with quite an appreciative glance, for he was well aware of the game for a husband which was then in progress.

After some conversation, which was an odd jumble of fashion on the part of Mrs. Smith, sentiment on that of her daughter, sporting on that of cousin Jack, and commercial affairs on the part of the merchant and his son, a waiter was brought in containing fruits and
wine. Miss Smith did the honors so gracefully, and had so many witty or sentimental toasts to propose, that when the hour of departure at length arrived, our hero was in quite a state of exhilaration. He squeezed Miss Smith's hand at parting, and breathed a few words in the vicinity of her long curls, which caused her to blush and smile sweetly as she said—
"She would think of it."

With the assistance of Medler, Grandval was safely seated in a cab; for, to tell the truth, he was not in the habit of drinking, and the wine he had taken produced such a confusion in his brain, that he was not very capable of judging which would be the best method of getting into the vehicle; but seemed to have a very decided opinion that to climb over the back part, would be the most eligible.

Medler at last succeeded in depositing him in his own room in safety, and left him to his slumbers, with the comfortable conviction in his own mind, that his young friend had decidedly committed himself to his fair cousin; and unless he had more nerve than he gave him credit for possession, Miss Kate Smith would soon be Mrs. Grandval.

On the following morning, our hero awoke with a violent head-ache, and a feeling of decided disgust toward the reminiscenses of the past evening. It was late in the day, and he hastily rang his bell; a servant soon answered the summons, and he ordered soda water and a shower bath. When the man returned, on the waiter beside the soda bottle, lay a delicate rose-colored billet, sealed with Cupid's bow, and highly perfumed.
"Where did this come from?" he asked in surprise.
"Mr. Medler met me on the stairs, and told me to deliver it to you, sir."

With many misgivings, Grandval took the note, and motioned to the man to leave him alone. With nervous trepidation he broke the seal, and in the tiniest and most elegant caligraphy, he found merely an invitation from, Mrs. Smith to a musical soirée at her house on the following evening. To this, Miss Smith had added on her behalf a few lines, hoping they would not be disappointed in seeing him, and hinting very intelligibly, that a call would in the meantime be very acceptable.
"Your parting words," concluded the young lady, "gave rise to many waking visions of a most Eden-like nature, and when I slept, the same rosy hues pervaded my dreams.

"What the deuce did I say?" thought the bewildered youth. "I have not the slightest recollection of what occurred for half an hour before I left. I surely did not make love to this 'counterfeit presentment' of my adorable Mary."

While endeavoring to recall the events of the latter portion of his visit, he completed his toilette, and having ascertained that Medler was in his room, proceeded thither to demand an explanation of that gentleman; for as Miss Smith signed herself Kate and not Mary, his perfidious confidant must have been fully aware that she was not the lady he sought.
He found Medler seated in a chair which rested on two legs, with his feet mounted on the back of another, while he enjoyed the delights of a cigar.

"Come in, old fellow—glad to see you all right. Pretty well used up last night, eh? What with the wine, and the bright eyes of my handsome cousin, you were quite bewildered, or enthused, to use a convenient word of modern carriage. Sit down, and make yourself comfortable. Had a note from Kate this morning, I know. What did the sweet sparkler have to say?"
Grandval sat down, looking very grave.

"So her name is Kate, and yet you took me to visit her, when I expressly stated that my Miss Smith is named Mary. Why have you acted thus, Mr. Medler? I confided in you in good faith, and certainly expected to be treated differently."

"My dear boy, do not take this affair so seriously, or I shall never pardon myself. These Smiths are charming people and very agreeable acquaintances. To tell you the simple truth, I thought, as Mary Smith is only a passing steamboat acquaintance, you might find her rivaled by her interesting namesake, although she had the misfortune to have been baptized Kate instead of Mary. She is a lovely girl—nay, a splendid one, in my opinion, and in that of many others too, for Kate Smith is quite a toast in a certain set, which is well entitled to rank among the upper ten."

"All that may be very true, Mr. Medler, but she is not the girl I am in search of, and you knew she was not, when you took me to see her. I am aware that I made a fool of myself last night, after drinking the wine which your fair friend almost forced on me, and this note is the result. Read it—as you are doubtless familiar with her tactics it can be no violation of confidence."

"There you're mistaken," replied Medler coolly. "It would take a wiser man than Napoleon and Wellington together, to understand the tactics of any woman; but I have no objection to read Kate's note. She is a devilish smart girl, and always writes to the purpose. Hum—invitation to a party. Of course you'll accept; for it is something to again the entree to such a fashionable house as that of my cousin's the Jeremiah Smiths. Eden-like, rose-hued—ah—h—girlish nonsense—nothing more. I dare say Kate has said as much to twenty others, and nothing came of it. You see she is still Miss Smith."
"And Miss Smith she is likely to remain so far as I am concerned," replied Grandval deceidedly, "therefore I considered it best to decline this invitation."

"Afraid to trust yourself in such fascinating society, eh? Well, if that is your motive, I cannot blame you. Kate is a charming girl, and not used to be slighted; but I dare say I can make an apology that will be received But really, now, Grandval, I think you are too scrupulous. Take the goods the gods provide, and be thankful. I thought I was doing quite a good thing for you, when I introduced you into a family of consideration like that of the Jeremiah Smiths. You know a stranger may be rich, well bred, and all that, and yet fail to get in a good set in a city like New York, for want of proper introductions."

Medler saw his advantage, and hastened to follow it up with so many arguments in favor of accepting the invitation that at last Grandval yielded. The next concession to be obtained was a morning call, which Medler had predetermined should be a tète a tète between his fair cousin and his young friend; but this Grandval anticipated, and insisted so decidedly on his remaining in the room during the few moments devoted to a fashionable visit, that he was compelled to yield.

These prelimnaries arranged, they entered Medler's cab and soon arrived at the door of Mr. Jeremiah Smith. The parlors were judiciously darkened, and Miss Kate overdressed but looking very handsome, received them with great empressement. Fearing her manner might be too demonstrative, and our young gentleman take the alarm, Medler found means to whisper,
"Be cautious, Kate—the bird is shy."

Thus warned, Miss Smith played her part admirably; sprightly, graceful, and amusing she detained them more than half an hour beyond the orthodox limits of a fashionable morning call, and on their return Grandval voluntarily acknowledged to Medler, that she was "very fascinating."
This was duly reported to Miss Smith, and with great elation of spirits she prepared for a coup de main at the soiree.

In due time Mr. Medler presented himself at the mansion of Mr. Jeremiah Smith on the appointed evening, accompanied by his young friend. On entering the hall, they were greeted with notes of preparation in the shape of long drawn sounds from a bass viol, which seemed like prolonged snores suddenly broken off. This was accompanied by the squeaking of wind-instruments, and no wonder they gave forth distorted sounds, for human ingenuity seemed to have tortured itself to produce such hideous inventions as many of them were.
These instruments were presided over by dark snuffy-looking gentleman, with a superfluity of moustache and whiskers, and very luxurious crops of hair.

Miss Smith, dressed as a soi disant representative of St. Cecilia, stood beside a harp which was ornamented with wreaths of artificial flowers, she had a very vague idea of the costume properly belonging to the patroness of music, for in the pictures of that saintly lady which she had seen, there was a scantiness of attire which might be appropriate to a saint, but would certainly have argued a deficiency in laces and muslins on the part of her earthly representative, had she closely imitated her model.

Miss Smith considered her costume a happy and medium between modern fashion and classic taste. Over a white silk under-dress, she wore several skirts of gossamer material, embroidered at the edges in an oak-leaf pattern which had quite a rich effect. Her arms were bare to the shoulder, and glittering with bracelets; her dress was cut very low on the bosom, and a species of Roman toga made of lace and embroidered to match her dress, was thrown over her fair neck, and fastened over the left shoulder with an immense cameo. Her hair was drawn back and twisted in a classic knot at the back of the head, from which a few curls escaped, and her brow was encircled with a wreath of laurel.

Grandval was quite struck with her appearance and agreed with Mr. Medler's asertion, that she was a magnificent looking girl, and would reflect honor upon the man who should be so fortunate as to win her consent to take him for better or for worse.

It had occurred to Mrs. Smith, that as her daughter was dressed in character, it would be quite as appropriate for the mistress of the mansion to be so too, and she accordingly decided to appear as Minerva; the only token thereof being a sort of helmet made of-black velvet and surmounted by a plume of marabout feathers; the last being an innovation of her own, and considered by her as quite an improvement. The remainder of her dress was in the height of the last fashion plate, consequently Minerva would have been at a loss to recognize her representative, had she looked in on the assemblage.

On this occasion Miss Angelica Smith, the second daughter, who was quite a musical prodigy, was permitted to appear in society. She was a young lady of tall and rather attenuated proportions, who looked as if she had outgrown her clothes; for her dress was absurdly short, and was eked out by continuations of pink satin, made a la Turque, and buttoned above a white satin slipper, certainly not of fairy-like proportions. She was sallow dull-looking, and seemed as if she felt herself out of place in a grown up assemblage, for although pretty well grown herself, she had been carefully kept in the back ground, and made to dress as a child until her elder sister should obtain an establishment.

Mr. Smith, looking as white and cold as ever, played the part of the courteous host and Mr. Jonas, as brown and dry as on their first meeting, accosted Grandval and seizing him by the button commenced a dissertation on the state of the money market, which was only ended by the united crash of all the instruments performing an overture.

Young ladies in white, blue, and pink, adorned with streaming ribbons of all the colors of the rainbow, and the gayest flowers and jewels, fluttered through the rooms attended by cavaliers attired in the last mode. Altogether it was quite a fashionable and distingushed gathering, and Miss Smith thought her new acquaintance must be favorably impressed with the position her family held in society.

Our hero we are sorry to say, had not much taste for the kind of music he was now stunned with. He liked a ballad, sung with sweetness and simplicity by some loved voice, and many of the negro melodies he had heard chanted by the slaves when at work in his native fields possessed a great charm for him; but scientific music he could not appreciate. He however applauded with the rest, and enthusiastically encored Miss Smith when she performed a solo on her flower-laden harp. This was followed by a very loud and very shrill performance by Miss Angelica, which the bearded gentlemen of the musical profession, pronounced "magnificent."

Grandval had no doubt it was so, but he had more than once been tempted during its continuance to seek relief for his tortured ears by a retreat to the balcony; and would doubtless have done so had not the contortions of the performer held him spell-bound. Apprehensive that they might end in spasms, he looked around for some restorative in case of need, and seeing nothing better than a pitcher of lemonade which stood on a side table, he mentally resolved on a shower bath of that should it prove necessary.

Fortunately the performance ended without any fatal catastrophe, and then there was a recess to allow refreshments of the lightest description to be handed among the crowd, for Mrs. Smith fully understood the impolicy of over eating for those who were to exercise their vocal powers, and her musical soirees, among her own set, had long since obtained the soubriquet of starvation parties.

During the evening Miss Smith had so successfully maneuvred as to keep Grandval near herself, and he was rather amused to observe the evident annoyance this occasioned to a small pink-looking man, with particularly light hair and eyes, who colored if any one looked at him. He kept a strict watch over all the movements of Miss Smith, and seemed amazed and confounded that she should over look himself in favor of any other person.

At the conclusion of the performance, when she arose from her seat this gentleman advanced, with a timid and awkward air of hesitation, as if to offer his arm; she looked over him in the coolest manner and, with a smile and nod, invited our hero to join in the promenade which the rest of the company had already commenced.
"I know you have enjoyed the music," she said, "for you have a soul attuned to harmony, I am sure your looks indicate it."
Grandval bowed, glad she took it for granted that it had afforded him pleasure, for he could not conscientiously say so himself, and he was too polite to be willing to confess the truth.
"Here is a waiter of refreshments, Mr. Grandval. Will you take something?"
"Nothing, thank you—shall I help you?"

"O, no—at musical parties it seems to me that we should forget our mundane nature, and only exist on the nectar of sweet sounds. Let us make our way to the balcony. Do you know that has become a hallowed spot to me since those happy moments I enjoyed there in your society?"

Grandval was naturally a bashful man, though no one could accuse him of timidity. He blushed at this avowal, and an observer might have mistaken his embarrasment for that of a doubtful lover, in place of suspecting the actual predicament in which he found himself, of being made love to by a very stylish and elegant looking girl.

Uncertain how to act, he suffered himself to be led like a lamb to sacrifice, and in a few moments found himself alone with Miss Smith on the balcony, for the remainder of the company were not so ethereal as she professed to be, and they were in the enjoyment of such creature comforts as had been provided for them in the shape of float, which consisted of an island of pink froth resting on a sea of skimmed milk, seasoned with sugar and wine. This was accompanied by the more solid edibles of sponge cake and candies.
Miss Smith drew her reluctant companion to the place on which they had sat a few evenings before, and turning her melting eyes upon him, with their most be witching expression said,

"Do you remember the simple ballad with which I closed our charmed interview on the evening of our first happy meeting? O halcyon hour, long to be cherished as the brightest souvenir of my existence!"
"I—I—am sure you will pardon me, Miss Smith, but—I—I—really, I have been so dull as to forget."

"Forget!" she exclaimed with a tragic start, while her eyes changed their languishing for a most upbraiding expression—"Forget! thus it ever is with your most perfidious sex. You practice your deluding flatteries but to decieve."

"Upon my word you misunderstood me," said the wretched Grandval, "I think you a lady of transcendent charms, and, if my heart were free to choose, I should doubtless have been deeply impressed by them; but, really, I must speak the truth—"
"What is it?" she faintly asked, "Is it not true that you love me, as your words led me to believe on the evening of our first interview?"

'I—I had no intention to deceive you Miss Smith. I am sorry that you should have misinterpreted mere words of unmeaning gallantry. Your cousin, Mr. Medler, could have told you that I am desperately in love with another lady."

"Unmeaning gallantry—love another," murmured the fair Kate. "O, cruel cruel, my heart is broken by the unmanly trifling. What did you whisper in my ear on your departure on that first evening? Words which I have dwelt on so fondly—clasped to my heart with such passionate joy—and they were mere professions; I grow faint, I believe I am dying."

There was no resource left for the unhappy young man, and he was compelled to offer his arm as a support to the tottering frame of the young lady. Her head rested on his shoulder, and her lips almost came in contact with his cheek, even in this bewildering position, his curiority, to ascertain what he really had said to her, triumphed over every other feeling and he urgently asked,
"What could I have said to produce such on unhappy crisis as the present one?"
"Said, ah cruel monster, you feign forgetfulness," gasped the young lady,
"Upon my soul I do not. I am serious enough, now I assure you."
"And you were not serious when you clasped my hand, and asked me if I would sing, 'Am I not fondly thine own?' when we next met?"
"Ah h," sighed Grandval, infinately relieved, "Was that all?"
"All," murmured she faintly "was not that enough?"

At that moment she caught a glimpse of a figure standing in the French window, and became extremely ill on the instant. Her form fell heavier on his arm, and he was about to call for assistance, reckless of what might ensue, when Mr. Jonas came forward and said,
"What on earth is the matter? Has Kate lost her senses, that she acts such a scene where strangers may see her?"
"I believe she has," said Grandval, hastily transferring the drooping form to young Smith, "If she has not, I must have lost mine. I will send Mrs. Smith, or the other young lady."

Thus speaking he hurriedly passed into the house, but as he had a shrewd suspicion that Miss Kate's indisposition was only a feint he did not trouble himself to find the representative of Minerva, but seized the first hat he came to, and rushing into the open air walked rapidly toward his boarding-house in a perfect fever of anger and indignation.

He saw through it all, and Medler's anxiety to take him to this party was explained. A regular net had been spread for him in the belief that he would be dull enough to be snared in its meshes. They had deceived themselves, and that was some comfort, though the reflection did not abate his resentment at being supposed a fit victim for so shallow a plot.

On the following morning before Grandval had arisen, two missives were brought to him. One was from Mr. Jonas Smith, demanding the cause of his singular escapade on the preceding evening; and very intelligibly hinting at the comfortable alternative of matrimony with his fair and broken-hearted sister, or pistols for two. Grandval had expected something of the kind, and had already made up his mind as to the course he should pursue.
On opening the other letter, he found the following words:
