"SIR:—Although I am not a fighting man, and am incapacitated from it by shortness of sight, and a degree of nervousness which is very painful, still I cannot permit my claims to be trampled on, and my happiness destroyed, without an effort on my part to avert such disastrous consequences, though I have never had courage to speak to Miss Smith on the subject, still a perfect understanding has existed between us for some time, that when I could manage to put my devotion in words, she would not reject it. I am a painfully bashful man, and if you have any sympathy you must feel it for one situated as I am. This his young lady is probably the only one I shall ever have courage to approach as a lover, while such a dashing blade as yourself may select among the fairest.

Pray take these circumstances into consideration Mr. Grandval, and withdraw from your pursuit of Miss Smith while there is yet time; for in case of a refusal, I must resort to the barbarous and uncivilized custom of the duels, which is so strangely sustained among a people who profess to be enlightened and christianized.
I shall the more willingly do this, as life will be shorn of all its promised joy, if you bear off from me the affections of the girl I prefer above all others. With respect,

P. S. Do not consider this last clause in the light of a threat, for I am emphatically a man of peace, and would very much prefer an amicable settlement of this difficulty; which settlement must, of course, involve the quiet resignation of the lady in dispute, to him who has prior claims upon her affections.

This singular epistle Grandval read several times, and in spite of the vexatious predicament in which he found himself, he laughed long and loud over it. Mr. Micajah Simmons was evidently a character, and but for the absurd rivalry in which they were placed, he would certainly have sought his acquaintance. He had little difficulty in identifying him with the pink-looking gentleman with light hair, who had been treated so cavalierly by Miss Smith on the previous evening. He seized a pen, and immediately replied—

"MR SIMMONS:—God forbid that I should take either your life or your love. Retain them both, I beg, and long may you continue to do so, is the earnest wish of him you have honored with your eloquent appeal.

Miss Smith is nothing more to me than the passing acquaintance of the hour, though I consider her a very charming girl, and am not surprised at your devotion to her. Since my visits have interfered so materially with your happiness, I shall cease to make them in future, and you may consider the field as indisputably your own.

Permit me, in conclusion, to give you a piece of advice. Overcome your bashfulness and give language to your passion, or some youth more enamored than myself, may step in and bear off the young lady from one whose devotion renders him so eminently worthy of her.
The reception of Mr. Simmons' communication a little modified his course toward Mr Jonas Smith. He enclosed that gentleman's letter to him with the following words—

"From the enclosed you may see that your fair sister will not be very materially damaged in her affections by our brief acquaintance. If, as I have every right to believe, Miss Smith wishes to obtain an establishment of her own, the devotion of Mr. Simmons places it in her power to do so; whereas a duel, and all the idle gossip which it must give rise to, will very seriously compromise her chance of such a denouement.

As to myself, I assure you, I am neither to be wheedled nor bullied into matrimony. My youth may have led you into the error of supposing me entirely inexperienced in affairs of this kind; but such is not the case. I have already been out once, and although it would be repugnant to my feelings to do so in the present instance, on account of the ridiculous misconception out of which this whole affair has arisen; still I will fight sooner than become an object of contempt to myself, as that most egregious of all fools, a man thrust into the fetters of Hymen without his own full and free consent.
Yours, with or without pistols, as you may decide,

These letters despatched, Grandval inquired for Medler, but that gentleman had wisely remembered a promise to visit some friends in the country, and had departed at an early hour, leaving this untoward affair to be settled before his return.

Grandval received no further communication from Mr. Jonas Smith, and he concluded the young gentleman had decided in the present instance, that "discretion was the better part of valor." We may as well mention here that, before the summer was over, or his own quest completed, he accidentally saw the marriage of Mr. Micajah Simmons to Miss
Katharine Smith announced in one of the city papers; thus proving that Mr. Simmons had profited by his advice.

Our hero, now left to his own resources, took to wandering about the streets, and reading the names on the plates, in the hope that he might find a John Smith whose residence looked as if it might shelter the object of his pursuit. He found this so tiresome a proceeding that he finally procured a city directory, and turned to the column dedicated to the Smiths. This capped the climax of his bewilderment, for among them were no less than thirty John Smiths, scattered widely apart, and inhabiting sections of the city as diverse as were their fortunes.

Still the quest must be followed; for, in addition to the love he cherished for the fair Mary, his pride was now enlisted in bringing the pursuit to a successful termination. Besides, he felt in his heart a deep conviction that this young girl must certainly become his wife, and no other. With this belief, he was only inspired with new energy by every new defeat.

"I must find her," was the first thought of his waking hours, and the last that remained with him before he lost all consciousness in his nightly slumbers Mrs. Wilson regarded his infatuation as a species of monomania, and vainly endeavered to dissuade him from any further attempt to discover his lost love.

Grandval now concluded to employ a cab to drive slowly through the streets of the city, and pause near the location of some one of the John Smiths, while he alighted and reconoitered the premises, with a strong belief that when he came to the right one some intuitive conviction would flash upon his mind that he had at last reached the desired haven.

Thus occupied many days and each evening he returned in a state of despondency; for although he found the homes of the Smiths, from the stately mansion of wealth to the humble cottage of the poor, he failed to discover one he dared approach with the belief that his Mary dwelled therein as a holy presence.

The cabman thought him deranged, but he was well paid for attending to so harmless a whim, and he looked as particularly after our hero as if he had been some lost child he was employed to restore to his afflicted parents. He continued this quest more than a week, and was really beginning to despond; when, one evening, as he was proceeding slowly through one of the thoroughfares leading from the city, an open carriage drawn by two magnificent bays came dashing up the street. It whirled past like a flash, but in that brief moment a young, fair face was turned toward Grandval; a look of surprised recognition and a salutation came to him at the same moment; starting up, he exclaimed:
"'Tis she, 'tis herself, at last! Turn, quick—after that carriage, driver, and if you overtake it I will double, treble your fare!'

Though the man did not comprehend the cause of this excitement, he understood the offer of increased pay very well, and as quickly as possible obeyed his command: but, alas! their horse was already wearied, and before they succeeded in obtaining another view of the carriage, which had passed at so rapid a pace, it was already half-a-mile ahead of them. Grandval seized the whip, and in a state of mind bordering on distraction, belabored the unlucky animal until he exasperated his wearied limbs into a gallop; but a few minutes convinced him that the chase was desperate, and he sank back in a state of discouragement, from which the recollection of the passing smile that beamed upon him, could alone arouse him.

As they failed to overtake them, it then occurred to Grandval that the occupants of the carriage lived in the environs of the city, in the direction whence it came, and if he remained long enough, the vehicle would return. He ordered the driver to draw up to one side of the road, while he watched for the re-appearance of the carriage, with the desperate resolution to stop the driver, speak to Miss Smith, and request the favor of her address, with a view of calling on her. This proceeding was, he knew, quite out of rule, but his case was nearly desperate, and he must resort to a desperate remedy, trusting to his eloquence to obtain forgiveness, when he could once more unrestrainedly converse with his idol.

Many vehicles of every description passed, and once our lover was deluded into the belief that he was about to succeed in stopping the right one, when the sound of a deep curse from a gruff voice, arrested his hand in the act of making a signal to the driver. Daylight waned, and the gas was lighted, yet Grandval still clung to the fallacious hope that she would return. Nine, ten, eleven pealed forth from the clock on a neighboring steeple, and still he seemed as much on the qui vive as ever.
At length the patience of the good-natured driver was exhausted, and he said:—

"Look'e here, Mr. Granwil, you are a very nice sort o' gentleman, only a leetle touched in the upper story, and I am willin' to let you have your own way wi' my cab consarn, as long as it's reasonable, 'specially as you pays well; but this passes mortal patience. It is now 'leven o'clock, and my hoss is in a starvin' condition; he have traveled pretty near all day, a huntin' up these Smiths what never turn out to be the right ones, and I think it's time for all rational people to go home, and quietly forget their whimsies in a comfortable sleep."
Grandval sighed deeply.
"You are right, Brian. There is now no hope that she will return. Drive to Mrs. Wilson's, and be sure to come back to-morrow at an early hour. I have a new idea which may lead to success at last."

"She will return," thought Brian, as he put his horse in motion once more. "Ah, I might a' known that a woman is at the bottom of all this scrimble scramble after the Smiths. Lord help the lad! there can't be much difficulty in finding plenty of gals of that name, though may be in the muss he can't get at the right one."

Our hero did not sleep much that night, but when slumber did descend upon his eyelids, he had most enchanting dreams of his charming Mary, and consequently arose the following morning in excellent spirits. Brian was punctual in obeying his orders, and he commanded him to take the same road they had traveled on the preceding evening. They continued to drive on until the open country, thinly dotted over with residences, was attained. Then Grandval checked their speed, and critically examined the different places as they slowly passed them. They at length came to a summer residence built in the Moorish style, and the yard was embellished with statues and vases filled with rare flowers. A closely shaven lawn was shaded by a groupe of fine trees, beneath which gamboled a pet deer, and a pair of goats, decorated with blue ribbons.

He alighted, entered the enclosure, and loitered toward the house, stopping by the way to form an acquaintance with the deer, which bounded toward him with the familiarity of a favored pet, as soon as he descried him. Grandval had not quite made up his mind as to the course he should pursue, and he was glad to gain a few moments for reflection, while he caressingly smoothed the glossy coat of his new friend.

With a quickly palpitating heart he at length approached the light verandah, entered, and rang at the door. A respectable servant appeared, and, he thought, eyed him somewhat suspiciously; he however replied respectfully to the inquiry our adventurer had resolved to hazard, as to whether Mr. Smith was at home.
"No, sir," replied the man. "Mr. Smith has gone to the city on particular business, and will not be back before night."
This was a disappointment; but something was gained in ascertaining that this was really the domicile of Mr. Smith. Grandval took courage to ask—
"Can I have the pleasure of seeing the young lady of the house in the absence of her father?"
"The young ladies have also gone to the city, sir, to spend several days"
"Ah," thought Grandval, "they were on their way when I met them last evening."
He sighed, and was turning away, when the man said—
"Any name, sir? The young ladies is very pertickler about the gentlemen as calls in their absence."

Grandval drew forth a card, and handed it to him. He proceeded slowly down the walk, so pleasantly shaded, and inhaled the fragrant breath of the flowers, with the intoxicating belief that the presence of his Mary had recently hallowed the very ground on which he trod.

He could not resolve to return to town, but dismissed Brian with directions to come for him to the same place in the evening. Then striking into the woods, he spent the day in the rural companionship of the birds and insects which inhabit the sports that man has not invaded. The Moorish castle was viewed from every possible point of view, and sketches of it transferred to his pocket book, to be retained as souvenirs of the auspicious day which witnessed the discovery of the abode of his beloved.

Late in the evening, Brian in some uneasiness of mind, returned to the place agreed on for he had many misgivings as to Grandval's capacity to take care of himself even for a single day, but he was much relieved to find him walking slowly toward the place of rendezvous, in quite a sane condition.

The following day was spent in a similar manner, for there was an attraction about the supposed residence of the fair Mary, that was irresistible, although he knew it did not then shelter her. Late in the evening a close carriage was driven to the door, and two ladies alighted from it. Grandval was not near enough to distinguish features, but he saw that the taller of the two, was about the size of her he was in pursuit of, and he gazed on her form as long as it was visible, with a strong inclination to rush forward, and claim her acquaintance. He however remembered that the day had been warm and dusty—and he had lounged about under trees in grassy places until his clothes would be much more becoming to a gentleman of his condition, if they had a through brushing. Taking this into consideration, he refrained from making his presence known, and walked slowly forward to meet his cab.

The next day he arose in great elation of spirits, and set forth upon his pilgrimage to the shrine of his divinity. At an hour suitable for such calls, he was set down at the gate of the Moorisa Castle. Wishing to enjoy the promenade to the house, he would not permit Brian to enter the enclosure, but commanded him to draw up under the shadow of some trees on the roadside. The bright sunshine was playing on the grassy lawn; the pets were frolicking in its beams, and accompanying them was a slender girl clad in white, with a green vail thrown carelessly over her head.

Certain that this must be the Miss Smith, Grandval was seized with such a fluttering at the heart, that he was forced to pause some moments before he could summon courage to advance upon the gravelled walk. She was stooping over, and so busily engaged arranging the ribbons on the collar of her deer, that she was not aware of his presence, until he came quite near, and spoke.
"Pardon me Miss Smith, but I have presumed on the acquaintance formed—"

He paused horror-struck, for at the sound of his voice, the young lady raised her head, turned quickly, and throwing aside her vail, revealed the face of an utter stranger! A face too as unlike that of the true Mary, as it was possible for human features to be. Brown as a berry, with a snub-nose, very full lips, and light grey eyes, she looked to Grandval absolutely hideous. She surveyed him with surprize, and then said—
"Excuse me sir, but this seems to me a very singular intrusion, especially as my name is not Smith but Jones."

Grandval could have torn his hair with vexation.—"I—I—really, Miss Jones, I have but one explanation to offer, which is that I have played the fool most egregiously. Pardon me for interupting you, and I will make the only atonement in my power, by retiring as speedily as possible. Good morning."
He was turning away overwhelmed with confusion, when a loud voice shouted—
"Hillo! young man, not so fast if you please. A word with you, before you go."
Our hero looked in the direction of the voice, and saw a fat, red faced man, attended by an enormous dog, advancing rapidly upon him.
"Mr. Jones I presume," said Grandval, with a polite bow, as he came within speaking distance, "I am very sorry, sir, that a misconception on my part, should have led to so unpleasant a——"
"Fal-lal—words—words—I know," interrupted the choloric gentleman. "Are you not the same fellow that called here two days ago, and inquired for Mr. Smith?"
Before Grandval could recover from his astonishment at this address, made in so discourteous a manner, a voice at his elbow replied for him,
"Yes, sir, it is the same, I'll take my affidavy of it."
Looking around, the young man saw that the servant who had answered his inquiries on the occasion of his first call at the Castle had advanced on them by a side path.

"I'm not disposed to deny it," replied Grandval with as much dignity as he could assume, "I was under the impression that a gentleman of that name resided here, and I called to renew an acquaintance with himself and his daughter which—"

"Well, sir," interrupted the fat man, "a gentleman of that name does reside here, and that is myself. I am Smith—Green Smith at your service sir; now what have you to say ssr, for you are no acquaintance of mine.'
"Nothing, sir, except that you are not the person I expected to find; and I will add that just now, Red Smith would be a more suitable name for you."

"While you appropriate my soubriquet, eh? said Mr. Smith, "I must acknowledge it would fit you well; any one could have told you that this is the residence of John Jones, Esq., who I flatter myself is sufficiently well known to the world in general, as one of the millionaires of our land; and I, sir, am his brother-in-law. Your intrusion, sir, is so unwarrantable, and made under so flimsy a pretext, that after the occurrences of last night, I feel it my duty to arrest you."
"Arrest me, and by what authority? For what offense? To what occurrences do you allude, that can give you a shadow of excuse for such an indignity?" asked our hero angrily.

"O, of course you are very indignant, but the circumstances are suspicious enough to bear me out in the course I intend to pursue. You called here two days ago, hoping by your genteel appearance to gain admittance as a visitor, when you could make such observations as you desired for the furtherance of your purpose. Baffled in that by the absence of the family you pretended to know, you lurk around the premises for two days, spying out their most accessible points, and last night your companions came, doubtless accompanied by yourself, and robbed the house of valuables to the amount of over a thousand dollars."

At this unlooked for charge, Grandval stood aghast. Amid all the difficulties he might encounter in his search after happiness he had never anticipated the possibility of such an accusation being preferred against him. He said,

"Really, sir, if this were not so absured as to be amusing, I could find it in my heart to be angry at having such language used to me. I am a gentleman as you may see, if you have any knowledge of what constitutes that manner of man."

"O, yes," sneered Mr. Smith, "You of the swell mob are always gentlemen I know, so far as dress can make you so, and your outfit is undeniable, however it won't do. I shall take you to the police office in the city, and prefer my charge at once, and I do not think there will be much chance to disprove either."

"I warn you, sir, that you do this at your peril, I can easily prove myself above all suspicion of such villainy as you accuse me of and I will not permit myself to be thus outraged and insulted, without seeking such redress as the law allows."

"I'll take the consequences young man, and I feel myself amply able to bear them.—Thomas did you not see this person examining the house from every direction for two days before the robbery was committed?"

"Yes, sir, his behavior was so suspicious like, that I took the spy-glass and spied on him, and he made drawings of it I am certain for he used a paper and pencil a many times, and he stood a long time a staring at the north window through which the thieves entered."

Grandval struck his clenched hand upon his forehead; he could have execrated himself for his sentimental wanderings around the home of the hideous Miss Jones, who stood an amused and interested listener to the conversation; and stared at our hero through a little eye-glass suspended from her watch chain, as coolly as if he had been some species of animal brought there for her especial examination. He asked indignantly,
"And do you really mean, sir, that I shall be forced to submit to the degradation of being examined before a police magistrate, on the charge of robbery?"

"I certainly do," replied Mr. Green Smith decidedly, while he patted his dog affectionately. "I would advise you not to make any attempt to escape, for this animal is an ugly customer, and would spring upon you at a motion of my finger."

"I shall make no such effort, sir. The cab that brought me hither is near the gate; permit me to write a few lines to a friend of mine, to meet me at the police court, and you will then see that you have been betrayed into insulting an innocent man. If I had robbed your house, I should scarcely have attempted to call on the family this morning."
"Oh, there's no telling the impudence of you gents of the flash order. Came here to make love to my niece there, I shouldn't wonder."
At this, Grandval looked so disdainfully at the ugly little brownie, that she dropped her glass, and turned away, while Mr. Green Smith went on—
"Well, well—write your note, and Thomas may go with the cabman, as there is no knowing but he may be a confederate."

The young man disdained a reply, and, taking out his pocket-book, sought for a piece of blank paper on which to scrawl a few lines to an old and well-known merchant in New York, who was his uncle's business correspondent, and through whose house he drew his own income. While thus employed, a paper dropped on the grass, which was picked up by Thomas, who displayed it to his master, with an exclamation.

"Strong presumptive evidence," said Mr. Smith, as he looked on the pencilled outlines of that portion of the Moorish Castle in which was situated the identical north window, through which the burglars had made their ingress. "'Murder will out,' as the proverb goes; and so, for that matter, will robbery, where it is quickly traced up, as I mean to follow this up. What do you say to this, young man?"
"Nothing more than I have already said," replied Grandval, haughtily. "You will soon learn that your evidence is entirely worthless, so far as I am concerned."

He folded the few lines he had written, and politely requested the company of Mr. Smith to the gate, as he wished to give his directions to the driver himself. That gentleman complied, and Brian, who had discovered that something strange was going on, was quite horror struck when his employer informed him of the dilemma in which he was placed and desired him to permit Thomas to take his seat in the cab, while he made all haste to the house of Drew & Co., and delivered the note with which he was entrusted.

"Oh! oh!" exclaimed the poor fellow scratching his head ruefully. "I never thought you was 'zackly non compos but I didn't expect you would get into quite such a scrape as to be tuck up for breakin' the law. Howsever, that are red-faced gentleman had better mind what he is after, I can tell him."
"And you had better attend to what you are ordered to do, friend," replied Mr. Smith, with great sang froid, "or you may find yourself placed in the same predicament as an accomplice."

"Oh, it's myself that is not afraid of you, nor all your kith nor kin, even if you could buy the town wi' your money; for I mind my own business, and cheat no man out of a penny that belongs to him. His honor, the Police Judge, knows me, too, as honest Brian, for I've been afore him as a witness more than onct."

"Then you had better interest him for your friend here, for he will soon stand in need of his good offices. Come, be off. Jump in, Thomas and be on your guard that no trick is played on you. Keep a bright look out, and meet me, in an hour and a half, at the police court."
"Oh, but he shall pay dearly for this ride in my cab," muttered Brian, as Thomas stepped briskly into the vehicle, and, giving a smart cut to the horse, trotted off in the direction of the city.

div.head: CHAPTER V.
div.p: CLOSELY attended by the mastiff, which showed his teeth and snailed if our hero diverged a step from the pathway, the two walked back to the house, on the steps of which Grandval was commanded to wait in the custody of the dog, and a gardener who was summoned for the purpose.

Very different was this reception from the one he had anticipated as he came out, and bitterly mortifying were his reflections. In a few moments a close carriage with the curtains securely buttoned, was driven to the door; at the request of Mr. Smith, Grandval got in, and was immediately followed by that gentleman and his dog. In utter silence they rolled onward to their place of destination.

When the carriage stopped, Mr. Smith summoned a police officer, in whose charge he placed our hero, and guarded by the two, he walked into the dingy looking room occupied by his honor, and his court. A party of Irish were before him, for engaging in a drunken riot; and their friends, a motley crew, were grouped around.

Grandval threw himself into a seat, and pulling his hat over his brows, endeavored to conceal his features from the prying observation of the loungers who always infest a scene of the kind. He earnestly hoped that Mr Drew would make his appearance before the case now in progress was dismissed; for it was terrible to him to have his name, and the accusation accompanying it, thus brought forward. He watched the entrance with intense interest, hoping every moment to see the wiry figure of his old friend appear therein, but time rolled on, the rioters received their sentence and were dismissed, yet Brian nor him he had been sent to summon, made not their appearance.
In a state of miserable wretchedness, Grandval heard the judge say to his captor,

"Well, Mr. Smith, I hope you have obtained a clue to the affair of the robbery, as you come before me thus attended. Since Mr. Jones called on me this morning to lay in his complaint, some of my gang have been making efforts to trace the perpetrators, but they have not yet had time to make a report; you have been more successful I see."
"Yes, I believe I have nabbed one sure enough, he puts on the indignant, and threatens me heavily if I persist in prosecuting the charge."

"Ah—ah, an old story. Those flash gentlemen are always innocent, according to their own account. This one, however, must be a new hand, for he seems terribly downhearted. Hillo, young man, look up at me, that I may see if I know your face."
Grandval paid no attention to this command and Mr. Smith commenced a concise narrative of the events of the morning, and the proofs of the prisoner's guilt, which he considered conclusive.
Just as he was completing his statement, a slight bustle was heard without, and the voice of Brian, in exulting tones, exclaimed,
"Hooroar, thanks to the blessed Lord, we are in time yet."

The next moment, a tall, thin man, with gray hair and whiskers, entered the room, followed by the two messengers, who had been dispatched for him. He bowed to the judge, and hurrying toward Grandval, said,

"God bless my soul! how could such a thing happen, as a charge of burglary to be brought against you? The driver has been giving me such an account of your late proceedings, as incline me to believe that he must have been romancing."

"I have been playing the fool, I sincerely believe, Mr. Drew, but I have done nothing to entitle me to such an indignity as this. Release me from durance, and I will give you a true account of the cause of my visit to Mr. Jones' house."

In the meantime Thomas had whispered a few words in Mr. Smith's ear, which caused
that personage to flush more deeply than ever and he seemed quite discomfitted when Mr. Drew turned to the judge, and said,

"Great injustice has been practised toward this young gentleman, Judge——I am Andrew Drew, of the firm of Drew & Co., as you already know, and I assure you that the prisoner is a southern gentleman of unimpeached honor, and independent fortune. If this absurd charge is instantly relinquished my young friend will pass over what has occurred this morning. If not, I will aid him in prosecuting his false accuser with the ut most rigor of the law."
Both the judge and Mr. Smith were well acquainted with the character and position of Mr Drew, and knew that his guarantee as to the respectability of the prisoner was quite sufficient.

Mr. Smith hastened to apologize for the mistake he had made, and even invited our hero to make another descent upon the Moorish Castle, when he should be more hospitably received than on the former occasion. Grandval coldly thanked him, and told him he was quite satisfied with his first experiment in that quarter, and had no idea of ever making another.

Ashamed of the part he had played. Mr Smith silenced the audible comments of Brian by a douceur sufficiently large to pay him four-fold for the seat his servant had occupied in his cab, and accompanied by that observant individual, he left the police office, and retired to the privacy of his own carriage, in which he was driven home in a state of great chagrin at the blunder he had made.

Grandval accepted from Mr. Drew an invitation to dine with him, and over their wine he frankly related to him the origin of the difficulty of the morning. He received much sage advice from the old gentleman, and returned to his boarding house, resolved to profit by it.

The services of Brian were no longer in requisition; and the whole family of Smiths appeared suddenly to have lost all interest for him. Mr. Green Smith seemed to have thoroughly disgusted him with all of that name.

div.head: CHAPTER VI.
div.p: IN this reasonable state our young gentleman continued for an entire week. Although his dreams were haunted by the sweet face of Mary Smith, he was firm in his resolution to be wise, and no longer seek one whom, it seemed, each attempt to find only plunged him into some absurd difficulty from which he was extricated at the expense of his own dignity.
This last adventure had so thoroughly disgusted him that he dreaded the idea of making another effort to discover her "whereabouts."

Grandval might, in time, have recovered his entire sanity, had he not unfortunately strolled into the rooms of a distinguished daguerreotypist, and, among the pictures hanging upon the walls, recognized the likeness of the enchanting Mary. In a breathless state, he sought the proprietor, and inquired of him the name of the original.
"It is Miss Smith. Mary, or Maria—I forget which is her name."
"Yes, yes; I was certain I could not be mistaken; but are you aware of the residence of this young lady, or can you furnish me any clue by which I shall be enabled to find her?"

"You seem deeply interested," said Mr. ——, with a smile. "I am sorry to say that among the numerous Smiths which adorn my rooms, there are very few I could undertake to find, and this young lady is not among the number. Now here is a Tom Smith, a Sam Smith, and a half a dozen John Smiths. I think so large a family should be as original in the selection of their names as an old gentleman I once knew, who had thirteen children, to each of whom he gave an appellation beginning with the letter Z. When he exhausted his vocabulary, he invented names, and some of them were curious enough to identify even a Smith."
Grandval scarcely listened to him. He had taken down the miniature, and was gazing fondly upon its fair lineaments.
"What will induce you to sell me this picture?" he asked.
"Really, that is rather out of my way. It is understood, when a man of my profession retains a specimen copy, that he will not part with it."

"It hangs upon your wall for all to gaze at; where is the difference in allowing only one that liberty? I warn you," he added, with a smile, "that if you refuse to part with it to me, your rooms will be feloniously entered, and this one precious possession abstracted."
"Oh, in that case, perhaps it will be better to let you have it at a fair price."
"Thank you. Remove it from its present setting, and put it in the handsomest locket you have. Put your own valuation upon it, and I will cheerfully pay it."

The fair image, enshrined in a golden case, was soon transferred to our enraptured hero, who placed it next his heart, paid the some what exorbitant demand of the artist, and returned to his own room to dream over it—to worship it—to grow almost frantic with the conviction that, if the original could not be discovered, the happiness of his life was forever marred.

At length it occurred to him that he would write to Miss Smith, detail the circumstances of their first meeting, that no mistake might be made, and then inform her of his fruitless quest after her charming self. No sooner was it thought of, than he commenced putting it in execution. After spoiling about a quire of paper, and consuming three days in the mental labor, he produced such a missive as he was willing to dispatch. Then his courage failed him, and he retained the letter several days, read and re-read it, made so many alterations and erasures that it was necessary to recopy it. This done, in a state of desperation, he hurried to the post-office and dropped it in before he had time to repent, though ten minutes afterward he would have given much to be able to recall it.

There was now no alternative but to wait for an answer with as much composure as he could command. One, two, three days passed, and he was almost in a state of despair, when a small white envelope, sealed with a bouquet of flowers, reached him. It was redolent of patchoules; and in an ecstacy he rushed back to his room, and, locking the door against all intruders, as carefully unclosed the precious document as if he were afraid of hurting it by rough handling.
Within was a sheet of highly embossed note paper, on which fair and flowing characters, to the following effect, were traced:

"MR. GRANDVAL: Your letter reached me in safety on the day after it was mailed, and, on reading it, I perfectly remembered our meeting on the boat, though pardon me when I state that your name had escaped my recollection. I have a singularly defective memory for names, though faces are never forgotten by me, and yours is not likely soon to pass from the tablet of one's fancy.

"I would comply with your request, and give you my father's address now, but as I am on the eve of visiting the country, I defer that gratification until my return, which will take place in two weeks; and, in the meantime, we can correspond. Letters are a charming medium of communication between kindred souls, and from their interchange we gain a deeper insight into the character of the writer's mind. The heart is more completely unmasked in the freedom of correspondence, and many things said by the pen that the lips would never utter.
"Then let us write daily, that when we meet we may be better known to each other than if hours had been spent together amid the social circle.
"Address your letters to the care of S. M., and they will be safely forwarded to me. Hoping to receive another of your beautiful effusions on to morrow, I remain

Grandval read and re-read this letter in a transport of extravagant delight, and he immediately set about answering it. He commenced with "Divine Mary," changed it to "Angelic Mary," and finally concluded that "Adorable Girl" would be the most appropriate address. He went on with such a passionate effusion of love joy and hope, that Miss Smith must have been more than mortal if she had not been flattered and charmed by his eloquence.

Her reply duly came, and every day for two weeks these mutual professionsof admiration were exchanged, until he was more desperately in love than ever, and considered his fair correspondent as positively pledged to become his bride. He discovered the most remarkable similarity in their tastes during this romantic exchange of vows. Miss Smith was evidently literary, and so was he; she believed in sympathy, and involuntary attraction, and these were two of his own strong points of faith; more than all, in one of her later letters she had ventured to assert that she believed Grandval and herself had been created for each other, and no other person could have rendered the other happy in the sacred tie of marriage.

His elation at this exceeded all bounds, and he replied to it by such a passionate outpouring of love and ecstacy that Miss Smith thought his feelings were wrought up to the proper point, and she therefore informed him that the hallowed spot of ground which sustained her angelic frames might be found in a cross-street, of respectable pretensions, which branched off from Broadway. She intended returning to her home on that day, and in the evening would have the happiness of receiving him beneath her father's roof. He would not find her entirely alone, for a young friend, who was in her confidence, had consented to bear her company; but she would be discreet enough to employ herself with a book, while her presence satisfied the scruples of her father on the score of propriety:

div.head: CHAPTER VII.
div.p: Punctual to the appointment, Grandval found himself in front of a block of houses, the lower floors of which were evidently used for stores, and he concluded that the family he came to visit lived above. He had very particular directions to look for a certain number, and on one side of the main door a smaller one would be found, bearing an old-fashioned brass knocker. A few blows on this would be the open sessame, and the lover speedily find himself in the presence of his mistress.

He found the door, struck twice, but before a third blow could fall, it suddenly unclosed, and a narrow alley paved with brick, and diml lighted with gas, was before him. He looked to see by what agency the opening had been so quickly achieved, and saw a small boy with a frightened expression behind the door, staring at him with all his might.
"Which way am I to go?" he asked of the urchin.
He pointed toward the dim obscurity in the distance, and said,
"Up stairs, please sir. The Gov'ner's done gone out, and Miss Mary is in the front room with Miss Sally Muggridge, a waitin' for you"

"Good Heavens!" mentally exclaimed our hero, "can my refined and intellectual Mary have a friend with such a name? Shakspeare need not say a rose by any other name would smell as sweet; for if Miss Muggridge were as beautiful as Helen, she would still be repulsive to one of fastidious taste, on account of that odious patronymic."

These reflections were made as he stumbled up a stairway, on which the dim gas-light only served to make darkness visible, while the whole atmosphere was poisoned by its exhalations. He reached the upper floor in safety, and saw a shaded lamp through an open door from which at the same time came a suppressed giggle.
A little disconcerted, he hesitated to advance, until a strange voice said,
"Walk in Mr. Grandval. My friend will receive you in a few moments. She is slightly discomposed, and has retired for a little while. Pray come in."
As this address was made, the round fat figure of a very dumpy girl, with a profusion of red hair, hanging in corkscrew ringlets over her rosy cheeks appeared in the doorway.

She returned his elaborate bow by a little nod, and stepping backward made way for him to enter the apartment. It was feebly lighted, but the extreme dinginess of every thing in it was not to be concealed even by that means. A dark colored carpet covered the floor, which dust and hard usage had all
JOHN SMITH, THE FOUNDER OF THE SMITH FAMILY.
most bereft of any distinct pattern—the tables were nearly concealed by woollen draperies which seemed to have been chosen of as dull a color as possible, that their neutral tints might not betray the want of tidiness, and on them lay a few books, which evidently had seen hard service. Heavy curtains still draped the windows, probably to catch the dust from the street without; for they looked as if a touch would bury one beneath an avalanche of the material of which we may be made, but from which we instinctively recoil in its primitive state.

Grandval was fastidiously neat; his early years had been spent in his light and beautiful southern home, and the vision of elegance blended with taste, which rose up before his memory, had unconsciously become his standard, and rendered him observant of strange little things which those of his sex do not often heed.

Miss Muggridge poured forth excuses and reasons for her friend's nervousness with extreme fluency, while he looked around him with a feeling of discomfort he was ashamed of. He endeavored to make excuses for the appearance of things, by reflecting that Mr. Smith was evidently not rich, and he lived in a wretched street to retain any appearance of neatness, for it was a constant thoroughfare, and it must be impossible to keep the house in respectable order. The most particular people would become discouraged after awhile, and suffer the dust to have its own way.

He thus reasoned himself into a more complacent state of feeling, and after uttering a vast quantity of words, which might as well have been Choctaw for any comprehension our hero had of them, the good-humored little chatterbox vanished through a side door, with the avowed object of bringing back her dear, darling, nervous Mary.

Some moments elapsed before the door again unclosed, and Grandval was beginning to become impatient for the meeting so unnecessarily delayed. It did open at last, and disclosed the fat figure of Miss Muggridge, leading in a willowy drooping form, which was as remarkable for thinness as her own was for embonpoint.

Grandval started up in irrepressible consternation, for this time he had believed it impossible that any mistake could have been made; and the thought flashed upon him that he had actually committed himself in writing to this lackadaisical girl, with a large nose, a slight squint, and a complexion as untransparent as beeswax.
"O," groaned the wretched youth, "this caps the climax of all my misadventures!"

He stood uncertain how to act, or what to say, a most pitiable object of bewilderment, until Miss Smith advanced quite close to him, and held out a hard long hand, while a smile gleamed on her thin lips. She spoke in a voice that was any thing but musical,

"Dearest Mortimer, for as such I feel myself privileged to address you, I bid you welcome to my father's house. How my heart has yearned for this meeting I can never express to you, but I am now happy, O, blissfully happy in your presence."
Grandval listened to this address in an agony of feeling language can not depict, and he could have gnashed his teeth in rage at the terrible blunder he had committed. He at length faltered.
"Do—do you really believe that we have met before, Miss Smith?"

"Can I doubt it? Your graceful form, your beaming eyes, your soul-stirring voice, all made an impression upon me that time can never erase. I admired you then, but your charming letters have completed the conquest of a heart overflowing with sensibility."
"O, yes," chimed in Miss Muggridge, "my sweet Mary is all sentiment and sensibility. She will render you the happiest and most enviable of men, Mr. Grandval."

"Good God, this is too dreadful!" exclaimed Grandval, goaded beyond endurance. "I—I—really, ladies, you must pardon me, but my own memory is to treacherous that—that I have not the slightest recollection of ever meeting either of you before. I am sorry to say so, Miss Smith, but a very singular mistake has occurred, and my letters have been received by the wrong person."

Miss Smith shrieked, uttered a slight exclamation, and fainted. The bewildered Grandval stood a mere spectator, while the fat little friend, with much ado, supported the rigid figure to a chair, placed her on it, and as she made not the slightest effort to assist herself, her feet rather ungracefully scraped the floor, while her long arms hung down in two straight lines, the ends of her fingers nearly touching the carpet.

Little Miss Muggridge then drew several deep breaths, which sounded very like the sighs of a whale, and violently fanned herself and her insensible friend with a bunch of ostrich feathers, such as are commonly used as dusters, but whose office in that house must have been a sinecure. When she gained breath enough to speak, she said:—

"I really think you are the strangest man I ever saw—to stand there like a statue, and never offer to help me get this darling sensitive creature in a safe position, when you know, too, you have reduced her to this condition."

Thus admonished Grandval aroused himself from his stupor, and looked around to see if any thing could be found which might be of use in restoring an insensible lady. A boquet of faded flowers stood on a table, and he thought the water in which they were immersed might be beneficial, as a tiny shower bath; he hurried forward, and seizing them, found that the vase was empty, and the flowers them selves artificial. They were in his hands, and with a sort of desperation he approached Miss Smith and held them beneath her nose.

However novel, it proved an efficient remedy, for she inhaled the dust with which long exposure had covered them, and it produced such a violent fit of sneezing, that the young lady started to her feet, and stamped them upon the floor in the vexation of her spirit. It was contrary to the rules of all romance, to have a scene so effectively got up, spoiled in so absurd a manner; for, who ever before heard of a heroine recovered from a swoon by the application of vulgar dust to her ol-factories?
Our hero certainly viewed its effects with consternation, for Miss Smith's pale grey eyes sparkled, her brown complexion actually grew red, and she turned on her friend reproachfully, and said:—
"Why did you allow him to treat me thus? O, false friend! I believe you wished to render me ridiculous in his sight."
Miss Muggridge was justly offended at this charge, she threw up her head, and shook her curls scornfully:—
"I need not attempt what you can do so much more effectually for yourself, my dear. I dare say, Mr. Grandval thinks the recovery the least absurd portion of the scene."

"O, my heart is wounded unto death," murmured Miss Smith, leaning her head upon her hand, and weeping. "The man who has won my affections by his insidious flatteries proves perfidious, and the friend of my soul treats me with unfeeling levity. I feel as deserted as Ariadne when she wandered on the shores of her lovely island, bewailing the loss of her Theseus. Mine, alas! is a worse fate, for I seem to have lost both lover and friend."
The tender-hearted Muggridge could not stand this reproach: she drew near to her, and placing her arm affectionately over her shoulder, said:—

"Forgive me, Mary; you know that I love and admire you, and it was you who uttered the first taunt. To prove my sincerity, I will endeavor to bring this gentleman to a sense of what is due to you. Are you certain, Mr. Grandval, that the unfortunate mistake which has occurred, can not yet be made conducive to your happiness and that of my friend? It seems to me an intervention of Providence, to point out to you the plain road to future bliss."

"I cannot agree with you, Miss Muggridge" replied our hero, who began to recover his self-possession. "Neither can I imagine how Miss Smith remembers me, when I have not the slightest recollection of ever seeing her before, and she certainly is an entirely different person from the one to whom my letters really were addressed."

Miss Smith uttered little shrieks at this assertion, and seemed on the point of fainting again; but as she was uncertain what other ridiculous remedy might be sought for by her visitor, she thought better of it.
Miss Muggridge turned to her, and said:—

"You hear what he asserts, my dear. Tell him when you met him; recall the whole
scene to his mind, and perhaps you may convince him that you have not played a part to entrap him into this visit."
Miss Smith, thus adjured, assumed a more perpendicular position, and, fixing her tearful eyes on Grandval, asked:—
"Did I not see you on the Empire State, in the month of July?"
Grandval started and looked more keenly at her; but in vain—he could not remember her presence there.
"I certainly did go as far as Albany on that boat, in the month referred to."

"And, and, do you not recall the fact that we sat opposite to each other at dinner? There was a small hump-backed woman with me, whom you afterward assisted through the crowd, and for whom you found a seat on deck, after we had dined?"

"I remember that incident distinctly, but pardon me when I say that I scarcely noticed her companion, and should never have recognized her in yourself. I saw that the little woman had no protector, and she was pushed about in the crowd; I extricated her from a simple impulse of humanity, and had no idea such an adventure as the present could grow out of an act of ordinary politeness."
Miss Smith sighed, and looked very downcast at this unflattering explanation. She said:—
"You will at least admit that when I received your letters, I was not to blame in retaining them and believing they were addressed to myself?"
Grandval bowed, and replied:—
"It was unfortunate, but I can not attach any blame to you, Miss Smith."

"Then," exclamed Miss Muggridge, impetuously, "I see no reason why you shal not make good your professions of devotion. As a gentleman, I certainly consider your honor as pledged, for my friend's affections are irrevocably engaged, and I dread for her the consequences of a refusal on your part to fulfill the contract your letters will clearly prove."
Grandval winced—he replied:—

"I am sure your friend has too much pride of character to claim a hand offered under such a misapprehension. The lady to whom those letters were addressed, I met while descending the Hudson; and to prove to you my sincerity, I will show you her picture, which I accidentally discovered in a Daguerrian gallery a few days since, and succeeded in purchasing."

He drew forth the image of the true Mary Smith and held it up. Miss Muggridge eagerly scanned the fair lineaments, but her friend, after taking one glance, shut her eyes as tightly as if she never intended to open them again, and hysterically bade them to take it away.
Grandval hastened to conceal it next to his troubled heart, and then ventured to say,

"As those letters fell into your hands through a mistake, Miss Smith, I trust you will not consider me impertinent if I request you to restore them to me before I leave you. I pledge you my honor, your own shall be placed in your hands at as early an hour as possible on to-morrow."
At this, the disappointed fair one grew decidedly hysterical, and she muttered amid such singular contortions as were far from improving her appearance.
"No—no—no. I can not relinquish those precious souveniers of the most thrilling event of my whole existence."
"But what value can they possess, when you know they were addressed to another person?" remonstrated the young man.

"O, I can read them—weep over them, dream over them, and delude myself into the belief that he who penned them was sincere in his professions. That he would not willingly break a heart he has taught to adore him."
To this outburst, Grandval knew not what to reply; but Miss Muggridge thought it the right time to attempt to touch his sensibilities in favor of her afflicted friend. She said,

"You must be aware, Mr. Grandval, that the professions in those letters you are so anxious to regain, would entitle my friend to damages before any court. My Pa is a lawyer, and I know something of breach of promise cases. This would make a fine one, I assure you. Had you not better make up your mind to accept my dear Mary as your bride, and save all the trouble that may ensue? I can tell you Mr. Smith is not a man to permit his daughter's affections to be trifled with for nothing."
"O," said Grandval, haughtily, "if your friend wishes to make this untoward affair a matter of speculation, I am quite ready to pay any reasonable sum for the possession of my letters."

"O, Sally, Sally, how could you be so barbarous as to insinuate mercenary motives to him whom you know I love so entirely, that I have not a thought or wish beyond the possession of his affections," sobbed Miss Smith. "Go—go, false man. I pardon you your perfidy, and when the sod rests upon my broken heart, you may be moved to too late remorse for your inhuman conduct."

div.head: CHAPTER VIII.
div.p: Glad to be dismissed, Grandval arose to leave. He heard Miss Muggridge say to her friend,
"Your Pa will not allow the affair to end thus, my love. Cheer up, I hear him coming up the stairway now."

In fact, a heavy step was heard, and before our hero could effect his escape from the room, the doorway was filled up by a figure that looked more like a wine cask set on a pair of slender understandings than any thing else. A red, burly face, immense nose, and a shining bald head were the most prominent of Mr. Smith's attractions.

As if his own house did not furnish a sufficient quantity of dust for his consumption, he carried a box in his hand, from which he took an immense pinch of snuff every few seconds, and liberally dispensed it over his face and shirt bosom.
He surveyed the party in some surprise, and then said,

"Hoity-toity, what's to pay here? Weeping and wailing Moll, when I expected that by this time you had reg'larly appointed the day. Good evening, young man; I hope you are not the cause of those tears, because I do not allow any body but myself the privilege of making my girl cry."

"An unfortunate misunderstanding which I deeply regret, has happened, Mr. Smith," said Grandval, with as much dignity as he could assume. "Unfortunately, it is now too late to remedy it; so with your permission I will take my leave."

"Not so fast, if you please, my young friend, Before you leave, I wish to comprehend the nature of this misunderstanding, and perhaps I may be able to set it right. I know all that has gone before, for my daughter has no concealments from me; and as you seemed to be serious in your offer, I allowed her to receive you to-night in company with her young friend here. How is it, Sally? Your tongue is glib enough, and you will have to explain, for Moll is in one of her die-away humors; and this youngster seems struck dumb by my appearance."
With great volubility, Miss Muggridge gave her own version of the story, which certainly placed our hero in no very enviable position in the eyes of the father. When she concluded, Grandval said,

"It is useless, Mr. Smith, for me to give you my views of this affair. I will only say to you that your daughter is not the lady to whom my letters were addressed, and I demand their immediate restoration."

"Softly—softly, young gentleman. Such missives are sometimes valuable in more senses than one. A lover's sighs may be made useful to raise the wind; the fragments of a broken heart may serve to repair a shattered fortune, eh? Don't you comprehend? You have a choice between matrimony or a matter of money, ha! ha!"
Grandval replied, indignantly,

"I have already informed these young ladies that I will purchase them, if that is what is desired. Pledge yourself to place them in my hands to-morrow, and in return receive a fair equivalent in money, together with those of your daughter, and I shall consider myself well freed from a most annoying position."
Mr. Smith took a huge pinch of snuff, and after a pause, said,

"I will take a night to consider of your
proposal, and my decision shall be made known to you to-morrow. Good evening sir."

As nothing further was to be gained, Grandval made a general bow, stumbled through the obscurity of the passage, nearly fell over the young porter who sat on the stairs asleep, and found his way into the open air, with a feeling of having escaped a fate he shuddered to contemplate

He made an irrevocable vow that nothing should tempt him to make another effort to find the girl of his heart; and on reaching his room, he heroically removed the beloved image from his person, and plunged it into the deepest recesses of his trunk, where its attractions could no longer tempt him to commit another folly in behalf of the original.

On the following morning, at an early hour, he was waited on by a gentleman of portly dimensions, with a crop of very red hair, whom he had no difficulty in identifying as the father of Miss Muggridge, even before he announced his name.
He entered in quite a bustle, rubbed his hands together, as if very pleasant thoughts were in his mind, and after introducing himself, said:—
"Happy to make your acquaintance, Mr. Grandval, though unfortunately it's not in the most agreeable manner that could be thought of. All in a professional way, however."
Grandval politely thanked him, and said he supposed Mr. Muggridge came on behalf of the friends of his daughter, with whom he had become so unpleasantly entangled.

"Exactly so, my dear sir; and I trust that after a night spent in meditation on the blighted hopes and withered affections of my charming client, you have concluded to be just to her and generous to yourself, in appropriating the hand and heart of one of the most amiable and most excellent of girls. I have known Miss Smith, sir, for years, and she is a paragon—a paragon, I assure you, and might with justice be set up as a pattern to the rest of the sex."

"I do not dispute Miss Smith's excellent qualities, Mr. Muggridge," replied our hero. "I am willing to concede to her every thing you claim, except my freedom. I made it perfectly clear last evening, that I had no intention to marry this young lady. The blunder I have already made is sufficiently mortifying without consummating my own folly by giving my hand to a woman for whom I have not the slightest preference. I hope you are the bearer of my letters."
"Why—ye-e-s—they certainly are in my possession," replied Mr. Muggridge deliberatively; "but I cannot surrender them except on conditions."
"Name them, sir," said Grandval impatiently.
"In fact, the party interested has no objection to bring a suit which must result in heavy damages."
He kept his eye fixed on the young man to watch the effect of his words. He smiled, and scornfully said:—

"Which simply means that I must bid high to prevent those silly effusions from coming before a jury, and covering me with ridicule. Name your price at once, sir; circumlocution will be of no avail, for my mind is made up.
Mr. Muggridge sighed—

"I regret it deeply, my young friend, if such you will allow me to call you on so brief an acquaintance. But really, now, is there no chance to induce you to heal the wounded heart of this young lady?"
"None whatever, except with a golden salve," replied the inexorable Grandval, decisively. "Again I say, name your terms."
Mr. Muggridge assumed a calculating air—

"You informed Miss Smith yourself, that you are a young gentleman of independent fortune; in case a suit is brought, the damages will be laid in proportion to your estate, say ten thousand, at the most moderate calculation—perhaps twenty thousand. The jury always levy a heavy contribution on the pockets of faithless lovers; which is quite right, in my opinion. Let me see—the actual award would probably be from three to five thousand dollars, besides the expense of going to law. Taking all things into consideration, I do not think a cool thousand too much to pay to get out of the scrape."
"It is too much by half," replied Grandval. "I am willing to give five hundred, and consider that as paying dearly for my folly; but I will give it, to be saved all further annoyance."

"But consider, sir, you disappoint the well grounded expectation this young lady entertained, of sharing your prosperity; and then you offer her in exchange for the priceless gift of her affections, the paltry sum of five hundred dollars."

"I have considered, Mr. Muggridge, and the disappointment for which money can purchase a panacea, is not very likely to affect her happiness long. Therefore I consider five hundred as much as it is worth; it is, at least, as much as I will give; and this is my ultimatum."

This was decisive, and after a few more feeble attempts to obtain better terms, the letters were exchanged, and Mr. Muggridge departed with an order on Drew & Co. for five hundred dollars, payable at sight.

div.head: CHAPTER IX.
div.p: SEVERAL weeks rolled by, and our hero had not once ventured to take a peep at the concealed miniature, for he dreaded that a sight of it would renew his restless desire to discover the original.

About this time Medler ventured to return from the country, and soon made overtures of reconciliation to his former dupe. Grandval, however, resented his conduct too much to accept them, and that gentleman forthwith determined to play some trick on him that should avenge his coldness. As his mind was fertile in expedients, he soon resolved on his course.

The suggestion he had once made to Grandval, to call a convention of all the Smiths, occurred to him, and he resolved to act on it without consulting the person most interested in its success. He forthwith sent an advertisement to a daily paper, which had a very wide circulation, headed thus:

q.p: "AN ESTATE WANTING AN HEIR—An eccentric humorist, lately deceased, left a considerable property in one of the southern states to a certain John Smith, a resident of New York, with whom he formed an acquaintance while traveling. The said John Smith having extended some ordinary civility to him, caused him to be remembered, and he bequeathed the whole of his fortune to him. An agent is now in the city who has the means of identifying the true heir, and he will be glad to receive the gentleman of that name on Thursday morning, at nine o'clock. His address is M. G., No. —, —— street."

div.p: Great was the commotion produced among the John Smiths, and they all began to recall his traveling adventures, in the hope of being able to remember the generous acquaintance who so handsomely rewarded ordinary civilities. Each one was convinced in his own mind that he was the true heir, and many joyful hearts went on their way to Mrs. Wilson's boarding-house on the appointed morning.

All the boarders had not breakfasted, and the man whose double duty it was to attend the door and wait on the table was kept in a state of distraction by the repeated demands upon him from both quarters.

On the first application, he was about to turn the visitor away, with the assurance that no Mr. Magee lived there—for thus he understood the initials given—but Medler had purposely placed himself in the way, and explained to the waiter that M. G. meant Mr. Mortimer Grandval, who he knew had made an appointment with some friends for that morning.

A message was forthwith dispatched to Mr. Grandval, who had not yet risen, and before his toilette was completed, no less than twenty gentlemen, of all ages and all sizes, were in the parlor, regarding each other with a most telligerent expression—for each one intuitively felt that the others had come to claim the inheritance to which he considered himself indubitably entitled.
At length the waiter rushed into Grandval's room in such a state of aggravation that he could no longer remember the respect due to a gentleman of his liberality, and exclaimed:

"For God's sake, Mr. Grandval, come down stairs, for every body in town is inquiring after you. The front room is full of—I was going to say gentlemen, but some of 'em don't seem to be that; but most of 'em are well enough in looks to pass for it."
Grandval stared.
"And what interest have I in these people?" he asked.

"I don't know, I'm sure, sir; but they all came to see you, and if you don't come down I shall lose my senses directly; for they keep a coming, and them that's there keep ringing the parlor bell to know when you will come down."
"This is very extraordinary; and did none of them send up their names?"

"They seemed to think you'd know all about 'em, sir, and it was of no use; but two or three of our gentlemen came along and happened to know some of 'em, and they called 'em all Smith. As sure as I'm living, I believe every man down there is named Smith."

Our hero started, and grew pale. He felt certain that a trick had been played on him by some one who was aware of his mad search after Mary Smith, but he had spirit enough to meet the Smith family assembled below without flinching.

It occurred to him that he might even turn it to his own account, and he drew forth the miniature of his beloved, and placing it in his pocket, descended to the parlor. He paused a moment at the door, to contemplate the eager faces and expectant air of the crowd within.

"Good morning, gentlemen," he affably said. "I feel myself highly honored by having so many good citizens to make me a call; and if I lived in your midst, I should expect that you came to solicit me to permit myself to be nominated as your next Governor, or at least as a candidate for Congress. Permit me, gentlemen, to inquire the cause of your appearance."
Thereupon arose a chorus of voices, amid which he could only distinguish the words, "advertisement," "fortune," "heirs," "John Smith," etc.
"Excuse me, gentlemen; but if you will favor me by allowing one among you to act as speaker, I shall the sooner be enabled to understand why you have honored me with your presence."
Thereupon a well-grown specimen of the race of John Smiths, who towered to the height of six feet two, drew a paper from his pocket, and, brandishing it above his head; pointed to the advertisement.

"This is our authority for seeking you," said he, in a voice worthy of his frame, "and it appears to me very singular that you were not expecting me, at least, for I am certain I am the person referred to."
"What gives you that certainty?" inquired many voices, "for I, and I, and I, am the rightful heir," was chorussed around him.
"Grandval waited until there was a slight lull, and then said—
"Permit me, gentlemen, if you please, to look at the advertisement referred to, for I am sure I am innocent of having any thing to do with it."
"Are you not M. G.? And are you not from the south?" was aked by Hercules Smith.
Our hero reflected.
"My initials are certainly M. G., for my name is Mortimer Grandval, and I came from the south."
By this time the paper had reached him, and glancing at the notice with so inviting a head, he said to the expectant crowd—

"I am sorry to inform you, gentlemen, that this is a hoax; and one I assure you, on my honor, I am entirely innocent of participating in. I believe the malice to be leveled at myself, but to that I am indifferent. I only regret that your expectations should have been so shamefully raised only to be disappointed."

There was an air of sincerity about him which, together with his graceful and gentlemanly bearing, impressed the John Smiths favorably toward him, and several shook hands with him on the spot, and hoped that this would not be their last meeting. He returned them his thanks, and then said—

"Since you have assembled here, gentlemen, I will inquire if there is one among you who remembers seeing me on an Albany steamer in July last? I had then the pleasure of meeting with a gentleman of your somewhat extensive family, who was in company, with his wife and daughter. I should be extremely happy to renew my acquaintance with him."

"Bless my soul! is it possible?" said a voice from the farthest corner of the room. "I—I had nearly forgotten the circumstance, or rather I was heedless, for now I remember you perfectly. Excuse me, Mr. Grandval; I am in affliction, and only accompanied a friend here who hoped to be benefitted, for I do not myself reside in New York."
As he spoke, a middle-sized, gentlemanly-looking man came forward, looking thinner and more care-worn than when our hero had last seen him; but he instantly recalled him to his recollection.
"I am delighted to meet with you, Mr. Smith, I do assure you. Pray how are your excellent lady and charming daughter?"
At the mention of his daughter, the father's face became gloomy, and Grandval felt himself grow pale.
"Mrs. Smith is quite well, thank you, but I am sorry to say that the failing state of Mary's health brings me to the city."
"Nothing serious, I hope?" gasped the agitated listener, nearly breathless with emotion.
"I am afraid it is. She is now confined to her bed the greater part of the time, and her disease seems to baffle the skill of her physicians."

To find her but to lose her, by the stern decree of death, was too terrible, and Grandval showed such manifest emotion that the crowd of Smiths had sufficient delicacy to depart, and leave him with his newly found friend.

"Mr. Smith," said he, mournfully, "I will not conceal from you that your daughter made an indelible impression upon me, and I have spent my time, since I lost sight of you, in endeavoring to trace you in this city, in the belief that you resided here."

"No, my dear young friend, I live in Geneva. We left for our own home on the same day we parted from you, but my wife and daughter have not forgotten their pleasant steamboat acquaintance; they have frequently mentioned you since. Mary must have taken cold from imprudent exposure on that night, for she has never been well since. Five weeks ago we came to New York to consult Dr. ——, and I now remember that my daughter said that she had seen you when out riding. Since that evening she has steadily grown worse, and I greatly fear that her days are numbered."
Grandval was overwhelmed. In the anguish of his spirit he related the history of his quest to the afflicted father, and declared that if Mary perished, the light of his life would be extinguished.

After a conversation of some length the two parted. Mr. Smith gave his address to Grandval, and invited him to visit him very soon, when he hoped that better news of his daughter's state might he imparted to him.

div.head: CHAPTER X.
div.p: Grandval wrote down the address, and carried it to his room. He placed it on a table, where he could see it at every turn in his troubled walk across the floor, and gave way to the emotions of mingled joy and fear that filled his mind. He would not believe that he had found her only to be parted irrevocably from her; she would yet recover, and be won by such true love as he could offer.

In the midst of his reflections he was summoned to breakfast, and leaving the card upon the table, he descended to the discussion of a cup of coffee and a hot muffin, for which delicacies he had very little appetite, for the sad news of Mary's illness almost counterbalanced his satisfaction in having at last discovered her.

Medler, hoping to witness a rare scene, had stationed himself in the room next to the parlor, from which he could be an unseen witness of all that passed in the interview between our hero and the Smiths. He was greatly disappointed when he saw how well Grandval sustained himself in so embarrassing a predicament.
He was vexed and surprised to find that the long sought one proved to be among them; and listened eagerly to the conversation which ensued between the two.

He still resented Grandval's indifference to the charms of his fair cousin, and his refusal to receive his own overtures for a reconciliation, still further exasperated him; until he was resolved to repay him in such a manner as should inflict as much annoyance on him as he had himself endured.

While meditating on the most feasible plan to pursue, he passed Grandval's room; the door was half open and looking in, he saw that it was unoccupied. In a comprehensive glance around, his eye ligthed lighted on the card of address; in an instant it was in his hand, and a new scheme in rapid process of formation in his active brain.

The address was written with a pencil, and the number thirteen on it, was easily changed to fifteen by a light dash over the last figure, which was very carelessly made. Believing that Grandval would much sooner trust to the evidence of the numbers on the card than to his own memory, he laid it down in great elation, and hastened to his own room.

In the afternoon, just as our hero was preparing to call on Mr. Smith for the purpose of inquiring after the fair invalid, an urgent message came from Mr. Drew, which demanded his immediate presence at the residence of that gentleman. He hurried thither at once, and after some circumlocution, was informed by him of the severe illness of his uncle, which threatened to terminate fatally. A telegraphic dispatch had been forwarded to Mr. Drew, requesting him to communicate immediately with Grandval, and inform him that by departing as soon as possible, he might be enabled to reach home before the fatal event.

The young man was deeply affected, for his uncle was the only near relative he possessed, and he was sincerely attached to him. To make arrangements for immediate departure was necessary, and together the two gentlemen went out to ascertain what steamers were up for the port of Charleston, and to engage a berth without delay.
Grandval returned at a late hour to Mrs. Wilson's, after completing every preparation for his departure on the following evening at six o'clock.

"I will seek Mr. Smith to-morrow," he thought, and inform him of the reasons for my sudden departure. I will endeavor to induce him to write me an account of Mary's convalescence, for I am certain she must recover."

With this thought he fell into a troubled slumber, which was interrupted by terrific dreams. He awoke unrefreshed, and in a state of great depression wended his way to the counting house of Drew & Co., where business imperatively demanded his presence.
When he was released it was to late to call on Mr. Smith, for his lodgings were in quite a different portion of the city from his own.
At four o'clock in the afternoon, he entered Brian's cab, and again set forth with that worthy in his old search.

"Is it after them Smiths, again, Mr. Grandval?" he asked, "I hope ye knows this time where to go to, for by my conscience I think that last scrape at the pollis office ought to giv' ye a lastin' disgust to the whole of the family."
"I have the address this time, Brian, so there can be no mistake. Drive on quickly to number 15 —— street."

Brian touhced his horse, and rapidly passed streets and houses, until they came to the required one. As they drove toward the number they sought, Grandval's heart sank within him; for there was a long array of carriages before the house, headed by a hearse; and the cold conviction came to him that his Mary was no more. A dimness came over his vision, and when the cab drew up in the rear of the other carriages, he had recovered so far as to see that they were bringing out a coffin covered with white, and a gentleman and lady he took to be Mr. and Mrs. Smith followed it, and stepped into the vehicle nearest the hearse.
"What shall we do next?" asked Brian in a low tone.
"You won't go a visitin' at that house this evenin' I suppose?"
"Follow the proeession," replied Grandval feebly, "I can, at least, see her laid in her grave."
"Blessed Lord! you don't say that the Miss Smith you've had such a time a lookin' after, has gone and died just as you've found her?"
"I shall never find her now, until we meet in heaven, Brian. Say no more, my good fellow, I can not bear it."

Brian looked very sympathetic, and when the slow march to the burying-ground was finished, he made some inquiries of the bystanders about the deceased, and the replies he received to them only served to confirm Grandval in his gloomy error.
"The young lady had been sick some time, but her death was at last sudden and the physicians had said it was caused by disease of the heart"

Grandval saw the remains of her he believed to be his Mary deposited in a vault, and without attempting to speak to the afflicted parents, took his way to the steamer in a state of terrible depression.

His voyage was a melancholy one, but some consolation awaited him at its close. He found his beloved uncle convalescent, and in his gratitude for this mercy, endeavored to reconcile himself to the loss of his first love.

Widowed in heart he considered himself, and he spent hours each day in contemplating the image of his lost Mary, in the full belief that no other could fill the place in his affections left vacant by her untimely death.

div.head: CHAPTER XI.
div.p: AS TIME waned, and the memory of his lost Mary became rather a pleasing melancholy than an acute suffering, a strong desire sprang up in the heart of Grandval to write to her parents, and express to them the tender feeling of reverence and respect which filled his mind toward those who stood in so near a relation to his lost love. We have said that he was romantic, and this desire perhaps will prove it, but the wish to offer sincere sympathy to those who had suffered so terrible a bereavement, also proved that he possessed warm and true feeling.

His letter was naturally and gracefully expressed, and was dispatched as soon as finished. He looked with much anxiety for a reply; it came in due course of time, and the revulsion in his feelings be imagined when he read the following words:

MY DEAR YOUNG FRIEND,—The reception of your letter filled me with pleasure, and also with astonishment. How so strange a misconception has occurred I can not imagine, but certain it is, that no such afflicting event as the loss of my beloved daughter has taken place; for she is sitting before me now, looking delicate it is true, but in no danger of a speedy departure to the land of shadows. For several days after our last meeting, we expected you to call, and I watched with some solicitude. I accidentally saw a list of the passengers on a southern steamer, and among them was your name. I supposed that you had been suddenly summoned home, and I must confess that I looked for a communication from you for many weeks. As none came, I concluded that you had relinquished your pursuit, just as it promised to terminate successfully.

Since you have so freely confessed your sentiments toward my daughter, I need feel no hesitation in saying to you that there is an inexplicable connection between her illness and her acquaintance with yourself.
